Posted: August 21, 2016
												Ever play a game that made you want to throw your computer out the window, and then 5 minutes later want to play another round?...that's NEO Scavenger.If you frustrate too easily, if you don't like random difficulty spikes, if you can't have fun when the game isn't "fair" all the time, if you don't like to lose... this might not be the game for you.You'll have the deck stacked against you right from the start most of the time. Just making it a day or two might seem impossible. Then you'll have that run of luck and manage to gather a small fortune, and even come to think of yourself as neigh invincible, only to succumb to some kind of horrible infection because you forgot to wear an air filter and accidentally inhaled some spores.This game is not fair. It wasn't meant to be fair. That's part of the beauty.There's a small but awesome modding community for this game, as well... and they've managed to add quite a bit of additional content to the game. Definitely worth checking out after you've played the base game for a while and want an expanded experience.

content:
Posted: December 10, 2014
												NEO Scavenger is a rather simple, yet in-depth post-apocalyptic strategy RPG game(woah lots of adjectives). You start off in a Cryo Facility and find yourself roaming a world ravaged by an unknown apocalpyse. The game is turn-based so you have enough time to carefully plan your next move, or end up perishing. The game offers lots of choices as to how you're going to proceed. Fight or Flight? Eat or not? Explore or abandon? The RPG elements are great and there is a lot of detail in the overall health system(pain, blood, temperature...), lots of possible customization, all of it affecting your player(having a rough air filter just might save you from an allergic reaction, or the inhalation of toxic spores). The game takes time to master and lots of luck as well, even after 10 hours I still find new things around the game(randomly generated map, but still unable to scavenge all of it), and still find the dumbest ways to die.10/10, slipped and fell, died whilst unconscious. (jk) PROTIP: Start with Medic and Botanist Perks.>I'd give it a 10/10>Pros: Leaves you to imagine most of it, great customization, detailed health and inventory system, replayability, hard and challenging, lots of points of interest, many more great things!>Cons: Sometimes you won't be able to really understand something until it kills you.

content:
Posted: June 29, 2015
												I will try to keep it brief and describe my games in a very brief manner. Each number, represents a different game from the start.1. I came out of the building, felt disoriented and not sure what to do. Something nasty came to me and attacked. I tried to defend myself but I bled out after the series of injuries.2. This time I had time to wander some more, I found some mushrooms, berries, sharpened a big stick and waited for trouble... but I froze to death.3. Shortly after I came out, the feral dog sneaked on me and attacked. I was fighing furiously with my punches, until I damaged his brain with concussions. I would have never thought that reading about the combat could be so exciting: bruises, cuts, bites, concussions, bleedings... all those details were amazing. My brain did the rest, imaging myself fighting for life with this dog. When he dropped dead, I patched up my wounds, took some painkillers and gutted him, took 2 small pieces of raw meat into my small medkit and moved along to find some clothes before I freeze to death again. I went to the city and scavenged it. I found plenty of goody goodies: crowbar with strap, binoculars with strap too!, cardboard box, cargo pants (with pockets!=more slots, yea!), T-shirt and some straps. Now, I am afraid to go out, because I don't want to loose all my treasure :( . T-shirt, cargo pants, hospistal gown on top of it all, holding crowbar in one hand and cardboard box with my treasure in the other one... time to move on. I go to the next building, I must be lucky, plenty of other  goods but I have no space to take it... First dillemma: break bottle and use it to make small campfire or leave it as a container for water later on? To hell with it... I might not live so long and I need warmth. OMFG! I had not enough points and had to end the turn, now the sun is gone... After a while it came out again, now I sit in front of a campfire, eating a cooked dog meat and think what to do next. The fire is not big enough, I move to the forest for more wood, some stranger attacks me, I try to talk to with him, he's confused but still charges at me... Time to cave his head in with the brand new crowbar. WTF!? He is some kind of a boxer! He keeps punching me and avoiding my crowbar! I cough up with blood and have got internal bleeding! After a short fight, I pass out and this guy is checking for loot on me... I wake up, beaten drastically, he retreated. MOTHERF**ER stole my cardboard box with goodies!!! I was on my way back to the camp when I have found an old car and a sleeping bag in it. Resting in the filhty but warm sleeping bag in abandoned IT office building, curing my heavy injuries, a mysterious horror creature woke me up. I had to run away, leaving my sleeping bag behind... After a while of running away, I had to go back, the cold rain has started to rain and it was a night... I know that my end is near but I keep sneaking in the dark trying to get into my warm sleeping bag... I just hope it is not sleeping in it... LMAO I threatened it with my crowbar and it ran away!!! I can't believe it!@ Sleeping, resting and healing in my precious filthy sleeping bag. After many hours, something is creeping on me once again. It's dark and we do not see each other yet, I will run away, I need some water anyways. It was a feral dog, I took some bites and I am bleeding but the dog is dead. I rest some more, take a bottle and go to look for some water, I find a small lake, drink a lot and take some with me, in a small plastic bottle.NO SAVE DATA FOUND... great... just f*cking great... Game is made in flash, so when I was cleaning my pc with ccleaner, it must have deleted some macromedia old cookies and my save file... how f*ucking hard can it be, to make seperate none-flash savegame file!?4. Tracked and killed by Merga Wraith5. - Chopped a poor fellow to death with a meat cleaver... He refused to fall back. No regrets.- WTF!? I met three bandits cooking something (I was hungry), there was also a terrified woman with a little baby in her arms. I had not a lot of options, but I think I have picked the wrong one! They have cracked her skull with a crowbar!!! " What happens next is not worth mentioning, apart from feed. You can't remember how long it's been since you have eaten that well." WTF HAVE I DONE!?- apart from all that, I am doing incredibly well. Got two shoes, nice clothes, meat cleaver to defend myself, made a campfire and cleaned some dirt rags for future needs. The only thing that bothers me is the guy with a rifle wandering around me somewhere.- ok he tried to kill me when I went to sleep! He shot at me! I took cover and now he offers to talk! Oh, no buddy I am coming to get your with my meat cleaver now! He keeps shooting and missing because I use covers, soon brand new rifle with a scope will be mine! Lmao, I chopped him to death! xD

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								"Do not get caught with your pants down. Pants? You start the game with no pants at all!"Oh dear...The game offers a good demo - http://bluebottlegames.com/main/node/21 so there's no cost to trying it out. The UI is bad, but the lure of trying again, and trying to learn and make progress is there, and it is strong. You will almost certainly not be impressed the first time you play it, but give it a second or third chance. It plays differently and presents a very interesting and realistic, though grim and unfair world to explore.I have enjoyed a lot of games that focus on sneaking and hiding but few made simple hiding as desperate or exciting as NEO Scavenger. You try desperatly to cover your tracks and hide before you end your turn. But that slows your progress... Hunger, thirst and the bitter cold force you to take risks. Plus you need stuff to survive, but unfortunatly for you, so do other drifters and vagabonds.Combat is unbelivably intense. UI clunkiness robs us of the full experience at least the first few times, then it becomes less about the menus and more about your, so far well going game, about to be ruined by a stranger. Even a weaker oponent can cause harm, wounds, and can alert other threats and lead them to you. There is no time pressure of any kind during combat, yet it allways feels dangerous or even desperate. You have to have some degree of faith that your choices will play out in your favor. They usually lead to your death until you learn more about the game. It's very much about survival, staying safe, luring other threats into traps or each other... and scavenging. Remains, food, parts. You're allways scavenging and the overall aim is to set yourself up for survival.First impressions count for a lot, and this game is Early Access which hurts it somewhat, esp. the lack of variety in a game where you die and start over so much. NEO Scavenger attempts to offer a niche gameplay experience, a bit like FTL or Papers, Please, where gameplay and style are different enough to make it something unique. Unfortunatly, it's current Early Access status makes it clumsier and less satisfying to play, and promises such as "This isn't even my final form!" usually end up dissapointing. However, this could be a very good game and trying the demo wont cost you a thing.Recommended for fans of turn based combat, realism, crafting, survival, adventures, Fallout, and games where graphics take a back seat to gameplay, strategy and athmosphere.

number of helpful: 32 of 58 people (55%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 26, 2015
												So I really, really wanted to like this game, because the amount of potential in this game is absolutely tremendous. The interplay between different systems and the really neat environment and design decisions should have made a great game.It didn't. There's not enough content for this game to shine, and because there's so little content the problems it has are made starkly apparent. Permadeath is not an inherently good or bad decision, but what it does in a game like NEO Scavenger is force the player through the same few bits of content over and over again. That content has an optimized solution, which means the first 5-10 minutes of every play-through are doing the exact same thing, every time, with no reason or reward from deviating from it. And then you end up at one of the pieces of game content that you _did_ play before, with functionally identical choices. And then you die, fairly or unfairly (and this game _loves_ unfair deaths; there are a number of places where you can die in a narrative scene because you didn't tag a skill!), and you get to do it again.A simulation game has to hide its brain to be deeply rewarding. This doesn't, and the narrative and the neat bits do not carry it through. Buy it for a couple bucks and play it once or twice, but at list price it is emphatically not worth your money because it will not respect your time.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												neo scavenger is a game that comes out of the blue in the steam indie market. Some games are good, because you remember the time you met that NPC that you felt engaged, and connected too, and of how believable they were, and because of the epic landscape that makes you feel like you were living an alternate reality then a program installed onto your computer. And then there are some that have unecesary and game breaking mechanics that is more of a nusciance and a story that fells like it was put together with no thought and imagination making the experience into an endurance test. so where does Neo scavenger come in, it is a role playing, post apocalyptic survival game with a top down perspective on a map that closly resembles to a board game. The game in my opinion is one of the most emmersive games i have played for awhile and i have considerably played enough to know the positives and negatives and heres why:positivesif you watched the trailer of the game, you would have noticed that it has still images and is text based, thats because it is. It is a turn based game simmilar to the rpg genre but unlike most turn based rpgs, your actions are in sync with the npcs. whenever you talk to someone in a confrontation you could be at risk at being shot with a range weapon because, when were about to talk, that person blasted your head off because it was their intention. you can sneak up to npcs and kill them but the problem is that you dont know who your sneaking up to. you could end up killing a harmless scavenger then a raider makeing confrontations even harder. the game does a great job at making confrontations meaningful and difficult to handle without felling cheap and half fasted.you woundering what the story is about like what most games have, well NEO scavenger has a story which is unique and enagaging. The world has many factions that has changed the world in their own ways, but it more happens in the background and what you do have little to no affect on them. Because you cant be a force of nature saviour or villian, it is because you are human. You do not have any special superhuman skills that games secretly slip into your character and instead make random events and point of locations intense. you instead have to think through things because if you don't your going to die, alot. Did i mention that when you die, you die for good and that you have to restart the game. This is the level of detail simmilar to darksouls, only more soulcrushing as the world is belevable and you are quickly reminded your human because you tried to play hero against a healthy dogman.The survival mechanic has been thrown around recently in alot of indie games because game developers impiment this, but end up copy pasting and being bland because they forgot what makes survival fun. The developers have managed to make the survival genre good in their game as it makes you feel like your recovering from wounds and actually hunting and cooking food. Whenever you attempt to patch yourself up or feed yourself you have to do it manually and organically, you have to think whats right and wrong theres no indicator except for the multiple bars on the right that can be summed up as your health bar. Even fighting feels visceral and brutal. The game uses text to explain what part of the body you hit on an npc and that npc can be   also knocked out through pain (the same can happen to you).negativesThe game has its annoying nitpics that i have witnessed throughout the game like, why do i have an imaginary pocket for my cash and, why can i reload my gun and patch myself up in ONE TURN like im the flash (whenever you acsess your inventory the npc can now have a prolonged turn because you were busy BUT ONLY THIS as you can manage your inventory for as long as you want and the npc can't do anything about it). There are the problems with the limitations of the flash engine as sometimes your save file could be deleted (this only happened to me twice).skills can be a mixed bag. You can be a tough, melee botanist but end up dying because you didnt have the athletic attribute that can help you outrun the dogman or a feble, frail survivor thats good at hacking, electronics, mechanics with eagle eye and tracking but died to a good punch to the face from a raider skilled in melee. I managed to stop this with a mod called big bad cheater which give you a defect called mega human that gives you all the traits and still make you feel human without turning you into a god. Go to the blue bottle site and search it up, instaling is dificult so go to youtube to get help.conclusionI remeber having fond moments with i fight i had with a crazed, infected man with a loaded bow, got shot, pulled the arrows out which caused him to beg for mercy after what he witnessed, and killing him with multiple hatchet blows because he would have killed someone or infected them with a disease simmilar to the plague (the hatchet is not in the game it is a mod called Mighty Mini Mod of Doom which adds more equipment and an extended story line. It also works with Big bad cheater, i highly reccomend it). Neo scavenger is a game that may not be for everyone so in summary do you want:*be emmersed in a believable world*feel more of a human than a walking tank*get into fights with bloody detail, simmilar to manhunt*organicly complete tasks and naturally survive with a permadeath system*actually care about your actionsif this interests you, buy it you will never experience anything like this. The developers have done a great job at making a game true to their genre and i hope that they make games in the future with this much thought and imagination put into them like this simply made but absorbing game.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2015
												If you like Fallout and you like survival games, Neo Scavenger is the game for you. It's one of the best RPGs I've played in a long time, with tons of exploration, meaningful choices with actual consequences, and tons of different ways to approach any problem. Most challenges are easily overcome if you're prepared, but the same challenges can still easily kill you if you rush in, and in most cases you only get one chance. Enemy threats are easily distinguishable on the world map, with all NPCs shown wearing the equipment they're carrying, which lets you guess at their faction, disposition, and danger level. Also, you get to kick a dogman's♥♥♥♥♥with your bare hands.Pros:- Exploration- Meaningful consequences to choices- Lots of interactions and events- Great art- Traits used often and in useful waysCons:- Somewhat limited variety crafting system- Crafting slows down noticeably when carrying lots of items, and may break sometimes- You -will- spend a lot of time playing inventory tetris- Be warned, this is a permadeath game (for those who this is a con)

content:
Posted: May 31, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok, to start out I want to say I love this game and any criticisms is because I want it to be better ok? Good! So in Neo Scavenger you are basically given one of two goals: A-Survive Or B-Story based playthroughs. to tell you the average life expectancy of any character is really not a for sure answer just because of the learning curve, this game takes micro-managing to quite a substantial level and unless you keep up with it you're gonna bleed out of your eyes and you won't notice because you didn't read the red text! Another great thing about this game is the combat system, rather than having a "Health Bar" it has more of a..."How much♥♥♥♥♥♥can you Eat Before you die" bar, now what I mean by this is you can take hits to the face with a Crowbar and still have a chance of survival, even though at that point you'd probably be "earing♥♥♥♥♥♥quot; thus the name! Genius! There is of course the as always Eating, Drinking, sleeping bars, but this game is kind of speacial due to it's tempature and pain bars, tempature is pretty self-explanatory so I'm going to stick to the "Pain" bar. It basically shows how badly your player is feeling so for example if he fell down he'd probably have a bum knee and that produces a bruise and minor pain, but if some dude rushes you with a cleaver and starts hacking into your stomach with it, he's gonna feel a little differently, And to wrap it up let's talk about the less than wanted things of about the game. Because of it's damage system and the random number generators you can sometimes get killed pretty ridiculously, for example I was killed once with a stick because he hit me in the head hard enough...Now while I like the damage system beacuse of it's complexity, that has to be fixed and I believe they are working on bugs like that, secondly the random number generator can be a real♥♥♥♥♥sometimes and even when you are supposed to be getting loot because you have a full loot chance bar you get nothing, I believe the developer is also looking into this. I really love this game and even though there are some rough patches I really hope the devolper can sand them down and hopefully bring this game to full potential! (Modding is involved in the game I did not cover it though because Steam doesn't have a Mod Page for it. Oh and by the way sorry for how long it is, there's just so much greatness in the game that giving it half a sentance didn't sit well with me.)

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								A brutally hard survival game. If you are feeling a masochist, pick this.Jokes aside, although the only control you have on you caracter is on the inventory management and choosing which actions to perform, I can assure you that this is one of the most complex survival games available in Steam. Due to it's level of difficulty, I suggest you play this on short bursts (as on the first playthroughts you won't last that long anyway :P )PROS:-Excellent atmosphere that absorves you into it's post-apocaliptyc setting.-The sound is great, from the realistic effects to the music.-Every choice has a consequence, even a choice as deceptevly simple as drinking a bottle of water that you just found-I would dare to say that the depth of the game's survival mechanics are unparalelled.-There is an actual main storyline to this game shall you choose to follow it.CONS:-It is a very difficult game. I have 6+ hours on this game by the time I am writing this, and I still take a beating every time. I tottaly understand if many people are put off by it.-The learning curve: I will be honest. This game has TONS of trial and error. Only after the first 5 playthroughs(about 2 hours of playing), you will be able to understand why you have died. From there, the game gets more satisfying, but adding to the complex interface and the fact that the game almost begs you to seek vital information (such as important crafting recipes) to the game's wiki page.Having said that, if you are looking for a challenge, you certainly have one here. If I were to call this game by other name, it would be Bear Grylls Simulator.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 10, 2015
												NEO Scavenger was on my wishlist for a long time, $15 seemed steep for a graphics/text game, let alone a rogue-like. Well, I got drunk one night and impulsively hit 'buy'. So now I have it, and I like it enough to give a review, which I don't usually do.NEO is brutal. This isn't the type of game where you play the ultra-altruistic "Hero" that saves everybody and looks good doing it. You'll live a lot longer if you take the attitude of "desperate homeless guy that doesn't want to get involved in your♥♥♥♥♥♥quot;. When you die, it's over. No going back to a previous save. You just start over from scratch.The learning curve is a little bit steep, but so rewarding once you get there. My first several hours I went through at least half a dozen deaths. I learned to avoid fights. To clean my wounds before bandaging them. I learned to not ever eat yellow berries. I rage quit twice. I came back twice.Now, I've got a rifle (with ELEVEN bullets!), a warm coat and enough clean water to last me a week. I'm unstoppable, king of all there is in this wasteland. Except that I'm not. I still run away from everything that moves, I only camp in secluded buildings, diligently cover my tracks behind me and always keep an eye over my shoulder.And that's how it should be. I survived for this long because I learned how to live in the wasteland. I didn't get a bunch of XP from slaughtering hundreds of enemies and then suddenly become immune to a bullet to the brainpan.That's what I love about this game. The "XP" is your own damn brain. Learning how to craft the things you need. How to avoid those looters in the distance. Knowing that I've gotten as far as I have by not making mistakes. NEO has an outrageous amount of complexity that you would never know exists until you go looking for it. If you're on the fence, just buy it. Well worth the money spent.One last tip: If you're new, take botany. Makes the game a little more forgiving since you won't really have to worry about food & drink.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 30, 2015
												This is an awesome hex-based/turn-based post-apoc rpg that I added somewhat casually to my wishlist and found myself thoroughly hooked on once I played it. The game is VERY reminscent, genre aside, of Darklands, in that you have several text roleplay adventures that can be encountered either randomly or in permanent places whilst roaming a decently-sized over map (I actually wanna play that too now!). You can also encounter enemies (and you'll sure as hell encounter them), gather in forests, loot in buildings, and just overall scavenge your way to your next safe haven... or unknown!The game is very fun and fufils that thrill/gamble factor with almost every action you take, as it is very luck-based with a few ways to bend it in your favor. It can be a little aggrivating on occasion (what game isn't?), but once you master what to look out for and keep in the early stages of the game, it seems pretty much clear sailing. Contrary to some of the frustrated negative reviews regarding permadeath, there is only a handful of situations where a player will die outside of usual combat, and most can be avoided by using your head and your wits. (spoiler example:  choosing to label yourself "stock" at a warehouse club which clears caters for some sort of human trafficking, i mean really :P  )All-in-all I would recommend this game to anyone who is comfortable with the genre tags; this gaming style is considered fairly dated by today's standards but it absolutely holds up, well and truly making up for it in storyline and gritty mortal desperation!

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												This game is really, really good.  It's got an interesting story, but you can ignore it and carve out your own tale if you so choose.However, I feel there are two problems with this game:Firstly, the world seems pretty much dead.  Except for one story location, there doesn't seem to be anyone anywhere except hostile bandits and looters who are willing to not murder you on sight if you agree to not murder them on sight.  In my opinion, the world should feel just a little bit more alive.Secondly, the game is TOO brutal.  I get that it's a roguelike and roguelikes are supposed to be tough, but there's a lot of things that, quite frankly, are full of♥♥♥♥♥♥I once stabbed a guy with a long, pointed tree branch made into a spear.  According to the game text, I viciously stabbed his upper stomach, and according to the in-game status text, he was bleeding heavily, in shock, and on the ground.  Somehow he managed to knock me out in one punch, steal my spear and backpack, and run away before I woke up, got an infection and died.Several times I've started a brand new game just to not find any early game drops and freeze to death within a minute.  No hyperbole, I died within a single minute of starting a new game thanks to the RNG.  Other times I'll be walking around the game world and suddenly I've got diiarhea and I'm vomiting and my stomach hurts and I'm dead.Don't get me wrong, this game is loads of fun to play and you should definitely give it a try if you like roguelikes and randomly-generated game worlds, but there's a lot of things that make me scream and swear at the game when I really shouldn't be.Overall, I would indeed recommend this game.  7.8/10

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 28, 2014
												TLDR:  A good turn based survival game with neat setting and mechanics.NEO Scavenger is a turn-based survival game whose difficulty I'd call 'tough but fair' once you get the  hang of the mechanics.  You play as Philip Kindred, a man who has lost most of his memories after being rudely awakened from his cryogenic-sleep pod in the near future.  The game is set in post-apocalyptic Michigan, with a mix of supernatural/horror and sci-fi elements.  Overall it reminds me of Fallout 1 and 2 in terms of tone and atmosphere.Something you should definitely be aware of before buying: Permadeath!  There is only one save slot in NEO Scavenger and when you die the game deletes the savegame, forcing you to start over.  However you can get around this fairly simply by manually backing up your savegame files after you save, so even players who don't like permadeath should still be able to enjoy NEO Scavenger if they save often and remember to back up those save files.  (I believe there is also a mod that adds multiple save slots, or that automatically backs up your save game, or something like that.  I never tried it out myself, so I can't comment on it.)NEO Scavenger is a text heavy game, and there is no narrator or voice acting.  Talking with friendly NPCs and fighting hostile ones both involve plenty of text.  Not that the game doesn't have a good UI too, but the lore and details of the game are all conveyed through text.Speaking of which, the story of the game is told rather subtly, which I like but some people might not.  You'll have to search for clues to who you are and what's going on in the world.  Talking to NPCs, investigating strange locations, even simply finding and reading ancient newspaper article could tell you something important about the world of NEO Scavenger.  My point is you are going to have to really explore the game to uncover the plot.There is an end to the story after which you cannot keep playing, but the game is pretty clear that going to that area is a fairly big deal and you are never forced to do so.One of my favorite ways NEO Scavenger tells you about the world (and lets you tell the game what sort of person 'your' Philip Kindred is) is through random events.  These events will pop up occasionally as you explore the map, present you with a situation/problem, and a number of choices to deal with said situation/problem.  They're a bit like a single-page Choose-Your-Own-Adventure games.  Though sometimes a bad choice can get you eaten, so keep what I said about backing up your saves in mind if you dislike permadeath.  I've found several dozen of them so far and the choices and their outcomes are generally very satisfying.  There was one that actually let me ask for more information before deciding whether to help a slightly suspicious person, which is something I've often lamented a lack of in other games.There's also a small modding scene, despite the lack of Steam Workshop support (flash and steam don't work well together apparently).  Check out the forums of the Blue Bottle Games website or Nexus mods for those.Finally, I just want to mention that the actual total hours I've played this game are at least twice of what Steam says it is.  This is because I bought the game through the developers website and generally play the version I downloaded there.  Speaking of which. if you do decide you want to buy the full game, you can get NEO Scavenger DRM free on Good Old Games, or directly through the Blue Bottle Games website.

								Definently one of the gems of Early Access.A cruel survival game, the developers eye for details is very noticeable in the world, characters, items as well as the crafting system. 												Brilliant game with a real feeling of fear and post apocalyptic gameplay. The problem with the game is that it is ridiculously chance derived and geared towards grinding. content:
Posted: December 17, 2016
												As a game, this is an admirable failure.  As an artistic experience, it succeeds, but not in a way that makes for a playable video game.  The bottom line, however, is that you almost certainly should not play it.The writing is excellent, and not just by video game standards.  The dev could write good sci-fi fiction.The game has permadeath.  The core game loop is good, but clunky.  Progress is punishing.  It takes 10 real life minutes to make a bunch of arrows, which aren't particularly effective, but they're what you get.  I recommend the sling.  Even taking all precautions, you can die instantly because a dogman or blue frog pops up at close proximity or in your sleep and kills you in one round.  You realize that there's nothing you could have done, and often there's nothing you can learn from to prevent it in the future.  Because getting a character into survival state, which allows exploring the story, takes several hours, the clunkiness becomes an insane ping-pong of clicks (left screen, right screen, ten ping-pong clicks to sleep; seven to scavenge a single building; repeat until you die or quit, then repeat some more).  I view this as an artistic statement about life that, like the sudden and unpreventable deaths, cannot be understood until wearily experienced.The problem is that the game breaks into choose-your-own-adventure encounters that are both the reason to play the game and what breaks it.  A majority of the options in these encounters will instantly end your game.  Single encounters will have branching choices, the majority of which will end your game.  They cannot be predicted.  Because of their branching nature and the immense real life time to get to the point where you see them, you cannot realistically finish the game.  Further, the game hard-limits your exploration; you get X number of choices, then time's up.  The internet is full of gnashing and wailing, true believers who spent over 100 hours on the game begging the dev to release the text files of the end-game, which he basically did by telling people what to search for in the XML files.If you do buy it, some guy made a batch file that acts as a save-game manager.  Get it.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
												I don't know, maybe this game gets as good as I keep seeing people say it is after you survive a little while and get some gear, but that's the thing: I can't. Every game I played started and ended the same way: I wandered around, scavenged for items, found nothing or barely anything (one game I found some pants; another, a multitool; every other game I would find a single shoe), then got attacked and killed. No matter if I tried to run or hide, I would eventually get attacked by an enemy and die. I couldn't fight, because I found no weapons. I was constantly getting sick, because I found no clothes. I'm all for games being tough, but when literally all I'm finding everywhere I go is dirty rags and plastic shopping bags, it's not fun. Maybe I'm doing something wrong and should look up strategies on how to survive, but I think games should have a minimum amount of playability without having to use outside resources, and this one doesn't, so I can't recommend it. I'm sad about that, because I followed it through Early Access and waited to play until release, really looking forward to it, but there's not holding your hand and there's not giving you any direction at all, and this game falls into the latter category for me. Your experience may vary.

content:
Posted: January 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger gives you an indepth survival experience without the system becoming too cumbersome. It's definetely a "One More Try" kind of game and each session feels completely different from the last. That being said, this is not a game for anyone looking for a comfy and cozy experience; NEO Scavenger can be brutal.The turn based approach is unique with regards to survival games, but it works here as you're given ample time to make the best choices possible. This is a good thing as the game can be very intense at times, especially when you're sick, injured or pursued by dog men.Props for the developer for inserting quite a bit of Michigan/Northern Indiana cryptozoology and myths (I'm been obsessed with  "melonheads" since reading through Weird Michigan on my way back from my honeymoon).

								I have never been a big fan of text-based games. In fact i tend to hate them. NEO Scavenger is the greatest exception. The traits you choose have the greatest impact on game progression and can save your skin or doom you from the start. Scavenge through destroyed towns and ruined cities praying you find any scrap of food or warm clothing before starving to death or freezing... the list goes on. Of course its unfinished so variety in items is limited but future updates are to come and are highly anticipated. It is worth the price and i promise you will be entertained for hours.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								(EDIT: Fixed a terrible typo that changed the meaning of one sentence into the very opposite.)Even during its beta stage NEO Scavenger feels like a completed and a released game. It can be intense (provided you have the imagination), it can be (actually it WILL be) evil and it can be forgiving (for a brief second before you run into a pack of dogmen who rip you apart).NEO is also ridiculously cheap for it's value. Of course, I'm not trying to encourage a higher price, I'm just thanking Daniel for his reasonable pricing. (Take that Metal Gear Solid V: Ground Zeroes)I can't recommend this enough. After getting the game I sunk a ridiculous amount of time into it in a single weekend. I recommend starting off completely blind. No wikis. No gameplay videos. Just jump in. After dying horribly a few times, you can begin checking a few things out from the wiki. OH and I URGE you to read all the messages at the bottom of the screen during combat (you can click the box to expand). Then just let your imagination fly and get all the horribly violent moments carved deep into your brains. If your imagination is anything like mine, you're gonna find this game to be one of the most ruthlessly violent games you've played and it doesn't even graphically show you any of the scenes.Now, I understand this is not a game for everyone. If you don't enjoy reading a lot of text, that is not a reason to stay away. You don't have to read any of it. But if you don't enjoy slow paced, the original Fallout-like games with survival and tension, you might as well stay away. But if you know someone who likes that kind of stuff, please, tell them about NEO Scavenger.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								To state it simply as I can, there is no way that I can do enough to recommend NEO Scavenger as highly as it deserves.  In the Kentucky Derby of the rather numerous games (a few of which have or are solid enough to merit at least some serious note) in this generally broad set of the Post-Apocalyptic/Survival genre of the current/modern PC scene, NEO Scavenger is a Thoroughbred Champion of the most uncomplicated sort.  The thundering hooves of the race set the pace out of the gate, nearly beating a tattoo on your ribs from within the moment you find yourself thawed and unceremoniously deposited into a world that appears to not only have been blasted and scarred by the now typical arsenal of Post-Apocalyptica, but also one haunted by Werewolf-like monsters -among a number of others-  that are both imminently fatal, but also understated in a way that for my own part recalls the same sort of creeping, crawling, truly psychological horror upon my initial encounters with some of Lovecraft's more authentically gripping horrors.  With a pedigree of the caliber that NEO Scavenger boasts for itself in my ever so discerning gaming tastes, the more atypical or "monstrous and supernatural" of the associations piercing my own memory and stretching all the way back to 1931 and the horror that rose from Y'ha-nthlei to consume and squat over Innsmouth as the Dagon's Deep Ones.  The second major thread is likely more easily expected and certainly open to being related to by a (vastly) wider audience in the sense of the overall and yet still growing popularity of the genre, this association springs forward over (the next two and three) centuries, bathed in the near incandescence of the white washed mediocrity of the just shy of unending faux 1950s Apple Pie-Americana and all consuming oceans of nuclear fire and equally inescapable Fallout.  In contrast to the almost stark bleakness that Lovecraft instilled in me at times - without being overtly apocalyptic; whereas Fallout inspired and from time to time continues to inspire the notion that humanity might well resist and rise again on the dark side of whatever Great Catastrophe it happens to be this time.  And it is certainly a blend of these personal, half-imagined (and again, doubly personalized) inspirations and senses of direction for my gaming imagination that are invoked upon finding my way out into NEO Scavenger's wide-open Michigan, a great American state that it would seem will take a little more than a single puny Apocalypse to wipe off the map altogether.I imagine that aside from being a logical decision for a one-man marching band, along with/and cost-effective from the angle of overhead and production costs, the old-school vibe and streamlined everything go a great ways in the direction of encouraging the individual player to engage the game in a way that other, more modern examples do not and cannot allow for.  Specifically, there aren't so many details, so many aspects of the experience predetermined by hard-coded and visualized default automatically and inescapably included in the Scavenging experience from the mouse click on.The Crafting System is a standout aspect of the Gameplay Mechanics for NEO Scavenger, which speaks to a bit of that aforementioned logic - it being pretty pointless to spend an entire game scavenging for junk that doesn't, or can't be combined with something to do or become anything useful.  The type and variety of that junk you'll be so happily scavenging is at a fair balance at the moment - though more melee and/or ranged (re: improvised DMRs/battle rifles) weapons of any stripe and variety, as well as pretty much any new items at all will always make me happy.  The combat system is similarly uncomplicated and crisp, though perhaps taking a game session or two for many of the more fast-paced FPS-twitchy gamers of the here and now.It's these invitations to the individual imagination that - along with the perfectly applied Game Mechanics- are the most easy and obvious examples of the true genius you can find here.  Or, to restate it again in final summary, there's so much about NEO Scavenger that will allow the gamer to become as immersed in and rewarded by their experience as the breadth, depth and staying power of their imagination will allow.

content:

								Although the graphics can be out right disgusting and the learning curve in the game is at an all time high. With countless early game deaths due to hypothermia or a nasty encounter. number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								So, basically you have lost all your memory after waking up from Cryo Sleep, in an abandoned Cryo Facility in an extremely cold Michigan.You then start looting stuff, most importantly clothes for warmth before the night falls and you freeze to death, then food, and then a weapon to have atleast small chances of winning a fight you might get into.The game has a very good story line, not gonna spoil it.What I like on this game the most, is that it's simple and complex at the same time.That means it's mainly hex 'n' text based, you will not encounter any animations besides rain and snow (if you make it that far, that is.)And you can simply just go around loot stuff and use them against people and for you.But you can also do alot more, like for smallest examples, boil river / lake / marsh water to sterilize it instead of directly drinking it and risking infections and illnesses.Or you could take a branch and sharpen it with a knife, or add sharp objects into it to make it a broad spear.The combat also, pretty simple yet complex.You CAN win a fight by simply repeatedly pushing the attack button, but you can also win a fight by playing much more tactically, luring people into traps, using the environment to your help etc, and win that fight even better without any injuries.You can either follow the storyline, finding out who you are / were, or you can just do open world play and survive in the harsh environment.It might look like a simple game at first, but I promise you that there's A WHOLE LOT MORE into this.The crafting system is VERY deep, and you can craft QUITE alot, I'm playing it since a long time (before steam release) and still haven't had every single crafted item in the game.It has a wiki with alot of hints and tips about everything in the game.Also, for modders:It has modding support, VERY easy at that.To add just about anything, that is encounters, items, combat moves etc.. you just have to add some new lines into the .xml file, and the forum includes alot of documentation on how to do that.I do recommend this game because it's simply awesome and has a very long and big replayability rate.Also, did I mention the map gets randomized every time you play (besides the story hexes) ?

content:
Posted: December 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								Half roguelike, half text adventure RPG/adventure game, NEO Scavenger is definitely something new.  I picked it up after watching a couple of YouTube videos, planned on playing for a few minutes, and found myself trying to beat a bandit to death with a rock while I coughed up blood.  Limping away from the fight, I died moments later from acute blood loss.It's a brutal but phenomenal game.  It relies heavily on your own imagination which, in my opinion, makes it that much more powerful.  It is one of the only games that captures the bleakness and terror of the situation.  One moment you're strutting along with a shotgun in hand, a smile on your face, and the next, you're panicking because you drank contaminated water.  You're sick, coughing, vomiting, and it's all over.  Phenomental, wonderful game and a great replayable experience.  Just be prepared to lose because it is a *difficult* game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 19, 2014
												NEO scavenger is, without a doubt, the best surprise I've got through Humble Bundle. What at first seemed a little interesting survival game turned out to be a massive and addictive experience, with the most detailed survival mechanics you've ever seen (except maybe Project Zomboid).In NEO Scavenger, death is considered a sure thing, the question is how long you will last for. Survive the cold, survive the wounds. Survive the infection, survive the unboiled water you were forced to drink because you had no way to make a fire. Survive the blisters you got because you hadn't found boots yet, while a dogman chases you. Survive the poisoning you got eating unidentified mushrooms. And worst of all, survive the people (NPCs) who want what you've managed to gather.The world has unique lore, setting a post-apocalyptic world with paranormal phenomenons happening left and right, but extremely well presented, gradually giving you the information, which is spread through conversations, pieces of newspapers and others.The atmosphere is similar(ly angsty) to those of Dark Souls, or EVE online, but more personal and centered around the desperate situation your character wakes up into, like Spec Ops: The Line.The combat is quite simple and brutal: He who connects the first hit usually wins. This enforces a visceral and all-or-nothing mindset, with no place for holding resources back, and a "shoot first, ask questions later" policy that makes you question your own acts as a player.Both combat and map gameplay are turn-based, and reward thinking carefully about your next move, since the game works with permanent iron man mode (dying deletes the save file) to ensure that you're adequately kept on your toes.Overall, this is the best survival game I've ever played, and definitely the best one-man-made game out there: 10/10

content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								Ok so this game is ... addictive. A nice post apocalyptic setup with one of the most detailed crafting systems I've ever seen. Also the game makes real use of the character skills, just like in old school RPG's - ain't got melee skill? Well, ain't gonna craft the best melee weapons, for example. As it is some kind of rouge like, there's no saving to be safe, it's just go for it and hope that you won't mess up, which leads to some pretty frustrating moments but also is part of the addictive character of the game. Closed the game more then one time during my 15 ingame hours but came back every time to start a new character. The combat system is kind of strange in the first few tries but as soon as you get the hang of it, it is really fun. It works turn based and you choose your actions as the enemies choose theirs, after that the outcome is shown in a textfield with lots of pretty brutal stuff, from arrows to the knee to wolffangs to your face. The graphic is not up to date, instead it is real outdated but this game is not about graphics, it's about imagination. Many encounters contain lots and lots of written text (remember Fallout 1/2 or Baldurs Gate conversations? - you won't find those conversations but massive ambient text). Features: - nice ambient text- great crafting system, starting from making glas shards out of bottles over crafting armor from hides and furs to upgrade weapons with scopes for example- huge bunch of neat items with degeneration- deep skillsystem with skills giving options on encounters (but skills are chosen on character creation and can't be trained)- big range of enemies starting from cannibal gangs over strange mutants up to paramilitary townguards (if you decide to attack them) - extensive character needs, from hunger and thirst over induced pain to warmth (yes, you can freeze and expect to do so often in the beginning)-rouge like: saving only by leaving the game, a dead character stays dead but a nice little statistic when died shows some of the players accomplishments - one of the most stable early access games I've ever played with a range of features and stuff that outruns some released games by far - big, randomly created (open) world with some points of interest - devs active on steam forumIf you like challenging games which are more about ambient then shiny graphics, show those devs some love and give it a try (there's also a demo which I highly recommend to play to be sure this kind of game suites you).

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 8, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm 27 hours in and I'm still learning a few things about this game. There's a lot of depth and possibilities.The decision of drinking water or not might kill you a day later in the game as you die of an infection. Some enemies have guns but no ammution, so picking up a fight might either be deadly or immensively rewarding. Dogmen can hunt you down in the night while you're getting some well deserved rest and kill you in a few moves. Othertimes you desperately search for a dogman to rescue you from starvation (They drop a lot of tasty meat). Resorting to cannibalism at one point in the game might result in an impossible to satisfy desire for human flesh later on.All the choices have consequences, many not immediately clear. This feels a bit arbritrary at first, but once you get to know the machanics you can use this to your advantage (there's a wiki that serves as a decent entry point, explaining most mechanics and providing a few tips, just make sure not to spoiler yourself). You can shoot enemys and then run away to loot their corpses later when they died of bloodloss. Or you can sneak up to sleeping enemies and hit them unconscious with a monkey wrench before they know what's going on.There's no leveling up, no new skills to get (there's actually a way to get a few additional skills, but you don't get them regularily). Your chances of winning a fight mostly depend on your equipment, sometimes you find a loaded gun on your first day and othertimes you're desperately searching for a way to cook your water.The art of being succesfull in NEO Scavanger lies in making the right decisions. If you have tough luck and don't get the gear you need or you're bleeding all over the place, you stay away from fights for a while. There's definitively a considerable learning curve, if you enjoy games with depth then this one is worth a look.The interface is not always intuitive and needs some getting used to, but then again that might very well change until the game leaves beta.I expected this to just be another casual game I spend a few hours on, but it really stands out and is loads of fun. It's very hard, but thats the way I like my games.

								Some games are not only fun, but they make you a better gamer.This game will break you of the all too common hoarder mindset.I'm a hoarder in games. I want to carry around every scrap of junk I find. I think it comes from the old point and click adventure games where every item had a use, so you had to find every item for that moment where you need it.That will get you killed fast in this game. Take what you need, set priorities, and for survival's sake, stop picking up every bloody rock and twig! content:
Posted: July 14, 2016
												Ah, this game returns me to the good 'ol days of dugeon master. A very nice, but at some times intense, text-based open world RPG is always a good way too kill time. I found myself trapped in this game for a few hours, trying every combination of character traits and items and shelters until I found the combination that best suited me. The game also includes a deeply satisfying narrative and atmosphere, one which lacks in many more complex games. In a simpler sense:Pros:+Unique, although simple, graphics+Satisfying narrative+Immersive and well-thought out atmosphere+Interesting and innovative game mechanics+Nice UI+In-depth interaction and self-interaction mechanics+Very interesting health system+Easy to learn, hard to master+Overall very nice feel and well-polished gameCons:-Lack of items (which is especially discouraging for an open-world survival game)-Lack of enemies-Narrative and discovery dwindles as the game progresses-Single storyline with little variationOverall:4/5. I really enjoyed this one. It has it's problems, but all in all it was very fun to play.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is the best roguelike to grace steam in some time. It's not about grinding, leveling up or anything like that. It's far more of a roguelike survival simulation. Only unlike Waywards island sim this game is more akin to the movie The Road or th S.T.A.L.K.E.R. series. It's desperateand meaningful combat involves you sneaking around, pulling people down, parrying, stabbing, swinging and doing everything you can to win. While a win feels great, the person you're facing is often in the same shoes as you. As for graphics everything is nicely drawn. Icons are easy to see and understand, the world is big but easy to navigate, the hand drawn figures range from average to awesome. It's not the best looking game but it's got a gritty atmosphere about it and it works great with the music.As for the sim part, this game just shines. Plastic bags will rip and you'll lose items, certain items can't be put into shopping carts because of the wholes in the frame, you'll be dumping pills out of small pill containers and putting them into larger ones so you can carry more. For a turn based game played on a hex grid, this is game can really get to you. I definitely suggest picking it up.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2016
												NEO Scavenger is a great roguelike survival RPG. Playing it, you really get the impression that the experience of surviving (or not surviving, probably) in a post-apocalyptic future would be this difficult. I recommend it with a few warnings:- It's a Flash game. That fact annoyed me for some reason when I learned it. Probably because there's no animation and it feels kind of "cheap." It creates the impression of a big, hex-based board game. Also, I'm not sure if it's because of the Flash-based game engine, but I lost all of my "map" progress when the game failed to save properly once.- The pixelated, retro-style graphics work, but they don't cover up the fact that the game is rather ugly--and not because of the apocalyptic setting.- There is some groan-inducing writing. Most of the writing is nice, though. It's not anything that detracts from the experience.- The game is random to a fault sometimes. You're going to come across things that can instantly kill you. Or they'll come across you while you're sleeping. It's not fun to lose hours of progress when a thug caves in your head with a monkey wrench because you picked a poor campsite...or RNGesus didn't give you his blessing.- Despite the game's randnomness, certain events never change. When you die, you're going to have to redo certain key events to be able to have a decent chance of advancing to the real progression. This can become monotonous after a few new games.- There are no save slots. This is unconditionally an ironman-mode game. That wouldn't be a problem if there wasn't the occasional corrupted save file.If you're interested in the genre and you understand that this is a game you might never complete because it's just so damned unforgiving, you can get a lot of fulfilling hours out of this.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 9, 2013
Early Access Review
								If you ever wanted a game that blends Oregon Trail and Fallout but with total emphasis on player response-ability (yes I mean response-ability) then go try the demo of this game right now. Although brutal from the start (I survived 3 hours my first playthrough), the more you play this game and the more time you devote to figuring out what skills/items/reactions will help you survive depending on the given situation (Hint: run) the more satisfying it is when you reach the point of gun-toting, berry-eating, sleeping-bag-sleeping, Dogman slaying badass, ONLY to die of diarrhea (RIP colon). And in the total stupor of "how did... that... why?" begin another playthrough and start the whole brutal endeavor all over again- BUT this time ready to defeat the mutated Detroit Diarrhea of the future with the knowledge gleaned from your frothy death (Hint #2: boil your damn water). Excellent! Fine! Stupendous! Here we go again! Thanks to procedurally generated environments, the game feels fresh every time you restart it. New buildings to scavenge, new bandits to hoot and holler at, and the realization that the best weapon of all in this game isn't your .308 rifle with 2 bullets, but simply the knowhow to just run the hell away and live another night. I will recommend this game to anyone I give a damn about and use it as a litmus to test to see if I'll get a hold of them when the world goes to♥♥♥♥♥♥ Thanks for making this and keep making great games!

content:

Early Access Review
								Hobo Simulator: Year Unknown, never thought id love finding an empty grocery bag...On a serious note:NeoScavenger's gameplay weighs heavy on inventory management and making the best of ALL of your surroundings, while trying to use your skills/perks. The decisions you make will make or break your adventure. You will die, you will learn from your mistakes and normally make it further each time you play. The post-apoc story is reminiscent of fallout but feels more like the movie "Escape from LA". This is a true rougue-like in nature, but its also a hardcore survival game with an immersive and rewarding crafting system. I find it quite addictive.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								4/5 Easily one of the most impressive survival games I've played to date. A lot of people might say something along the lines of ".. but the graphics aren't great at all.." and thats okay. But what this game lacks in graphics, it more than makes up for in the mechanics and detail.  It will suck you in, probably even make you mad a little bit, but thats the beauty of it! NEO Scavanger tests your wits and your patience. Your cunning and intellect. Crafting is a huge part of the game. You have to gather supplies and build shelter and weapons, tools and clothes, hunt deer and trap squirrels. Wasteland raiders and looters roam the countryside, so watch out! You can get inflicted with a crap ton of bad status ailments such as Hypothermia, Sephis, infections, concussions, starvation, dehydration, poison, internal bleeding, and much... MUCH more! It is very challenging and makes you think about EVERY move before you make it!Look... even if you know you don't want to spend the money to buy it (which is still only $10), it is at least worth DLing the demo. That's what I did... and now I'm hooked. Good Gaming,Yeticlone

Early Access Review
								A fresh take on the old rouge-like with great new game play systems that integrate seamlessly into the genre we know and love.The exploratory gameplay is engaging and nerve-wracking at the same time, and the unpredictable nature of events in the game means you'll spend much of your time simply trying to plan ahead for every contingency. This coupled with the constant threat of permanent death creates a very engaging experience. You never quite know what will happen once you step out of the Cryo Facility.  It truly defines survival, a lot of times on fresh starts I'd freeze to death on the first night since I couldn't find proper clothing, now that's realistic. There's a lot of potential here and I can't wait to see what the devs do with it.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is like a drug, the well known syndrome of "one more turn". There is always something to discover, something to scare you or something to kill you. After countless deaths by ghosts, dogmen, cannibals and once because of very bad diarrhea, I still come back to the game, trying out different skill combination. The semi-random layout of the map (random scavange locations + fixed special locations), there is always an insentive to explore and see the world. Random encounters make every venture to a city that much more interessting. The slow pace of the game is perfect for people who want to take it slow, or like me, need time to actually figure out what they want to do. Combat is also refreshingly slow, gives you time to think over your moves and select the best option at the given moment (will you headbutt your opponent or dodge his next attack, hoping he will be vulnerable to counter attack).I hope the game evolves in the same way, presenting us with more dangerous creatures that stalk you in the night and more unique places that make you sit for a moment and carefully choose your next action, because permadeath is never that far away.

								I have played A LOT of games this year. Not a single one has captivated me in such a short time as NEO Scavenger. This game's exterior is rather simple, but once you get in and start playing, you will no doubt be in awe of the depth of its mechanics. Give the demo a try and see what i mean... My hat off to Blue Bottle Games for what they have created.

content:
Posted: April 10, 2016
												This is basically "The Road" as a videogame. You drag a shopping cart filled with junk through a desolate wasteland, desperately scrounge for a meal, and the apex of your day is finding a shoe in working condition for the correct foot. You'll be lucky to wake up tomorrow and even luckier to still have your things.The game features an incredibly in depth health system, which makes you vulnerable to blisters, infections, blood loss, diarrhea, allergies, hypothermia, dehydration, starvation...and other awful experiences I haven't had the pleasure to face yet. Combat is possible, but very very risky and the odds must be considered carefully. There is some kind of plot, but I haven't progressed enough to fully grasp it. There are, however, occasional side quests and the writing is consistently very good. Try it out. I don't like survival games, generally, but this one took a hold of me.

content:

Early Access Review
								A pretty outstanding game.It's a hexagonbase survival strategy game, that stresses on finding equipment to endure the elements, finding food, water, and medicine to survive. In a post apocalyptic world, it's you and you alone that must brave the outside world where anything could be your enemy.It's a scavanger game, you loot anything you are able to and keep anything useful, anything from nuts and bolts to nightvision goggles and assault rifles. Eventually you will have a character that you have put a bit of time and effort into creating, this is where the game gets fun.I really enjoy this game. It just recently came out a few months ago, I believe, and the dev is already coming out with patches, and helpful fixes towards the game. So, there's always new stuff to look forward to.If you play scavanging games, and you enjoy the satisfaction of trying to survive as long as you can.Then, I suggest you give this title a try.It even has a demo; if you are still unsure.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 13, 2013
Early Access Review
								One of the best survival games I have played; where it's a dog eats dog world. Hunger sets in if you don't consume food, you can die from dehydration, freeze to death, bleed to death, die from infection and poison; the odds are stacked against you. However, the same goes for everyone else in Neo Scavenger, as well. It isn't like other games, where they severly penalize you but the conditions does not effect the enemy. Far from it, scavengers you find along the way can bleed to their demise and freeze and perish in the cold if they have no clothing, just like the way you can in the given conditions.If you pick this game up, be prepared to scream at times, and die countless more. Each death comes with learning to play better, and the learning curve is extremely steep. This game is literally based on Marxism, and it truly is a brutal, unforgiving atmosphere. Do not underestimate the enemy, and if you encounter two or more at once, do not be frugal. It's better to use that ammunition and live another day, than die and start over. Gear up and learn how to survive; and good luck.

content:
Posted: July 3, 2016
												I really, really wanted to like this game.  I enjoy roguelikes (I love Nethack) and survival games as a genre, but I can't recommend this one.In the end, it's too easy to die without any foreknowledge, making the game feel a lot like playing roulette.  In my most recent game, I walked into a hex that appeared unoccupied, but in fact hid a dogman who killed me before I even spotted him.  I'm used to dying frequently playing games like Nethack, but I always feel like it's my fault, or that there was something I could have done to prevent my most recent death.  I do not have this feeling when playing Neo Scavenger.The UI is also very cumbersome (e.g., trying to navigate the craft menus, or trying to move things around in your inventory between vehicles and a box, etc.), coupled with tons of annoying fiddling in order to play even near-optimally (like always making/lighting torches when you scavenge, or trying to put on the 3 best shirts you have found), means that most of the time you're fighting the UI instead of making interesting decisions.  The simple fact that you can't tell whether water in a bottle is purified or not without dumping it out exemplifies what I mean.  Instead of looking for a bottle [water (purified)], you just have to dump out all your bottles until you find one containing purified water, take a drink, then put all the water back in the bottles.  It's madness.

number of helpful: 7 of 12 people (58%) found this review helpful4 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 4, 2016
												Day one.I wake up in a cryogenic facility, Instantly approached by a hulking monster. Remembering my knowledge and previous work in a garden, I decide to smash plants against my skin to scare the monster away. It works. I proceede to leave, Gathering pebbles and bark for my future domination of the world.Day two.I find out that bark does not protect me from hypothermia, And decide to scavange for clothes instead. Finding a shoe and a t-shirt, I dress. From rags to riches, They always say.Day three. I am approached by a random man wearing a hoodie with a glass bottle. Thinking he is bringing me a gift, I attempt to speak with him, Only to have my head wildly bashed in with said bottle, The last words going through my head being; "I wonder if my shoe fell apart."----All sillyness aside, Neo Scavanger is an amazing game. It includes the perfect mixture of roguelike mechanics, Mixed with a interesting if sparse text based story. The complexity of the game itself is astounding, Considering that it's a flash. The only cons i could point out would be the fact that it is currently out of any major development, Though it is majorly bug free and full of content, As well as major modability in its current form. All in all, Worth the money.

content:
Posted: May 11, 2015
												Man I totally understand the love I see for this game but I just can't get behind it. I enjoyed this game and have alot of respect for roguelike game that manages to tell an intersting and detailed story. Ultimately the reason I have to give this the thumbs down is because of the terrible user interface and menu system that just flat out needs to be better.The game is a challenging one unfortunetly most of the challenge I faced was figuring out to navigate the complete mess of a menu system. Now once you get the menu system down the experience is much improved. I was reminded of how awful the menu system was after I had to put the game down for a few weeks and came back to find I had forgotten some of the ins and outs of the game and I just can't bring myself to try it again.I can handle bad graphics and some game play flaws but there are just too many here for me to ignore. There's some stuff to like here but overall its just not worth the price tag. 4/10

Posted: November 2, 2016
												This is an interesting game concept and nicely fleshed out lore (as far as i can tell) and i would very much like to see a more developed version in future.I do not regret having bought this title and see my small money as contribution to the developers further endeavours, but after some hours the gameplay feels to poor and unrewarding to keep on playing. Do not get me wrong, i like hard games, but this one feels of balance. Needless to say that combat mechanics are very outdated, but interaction with NPCs in general feel stale and lifeless and there is no good way to interact in a meaningful way - only stomping other peoples heads or getting stomped...I am aware that this game was developed by one single man, so hats off to you Sir. Hope we will see more of your work, but i will pass on this from now on...Bottom line: If you want to try it out, go ahead, but do not expect your experience to be particularly rewarding.

content:

Early Access Review
								I haven't reviewed anything on Steam yet, but I had to review NEO Scavenger because this game deserves so much praise. It completely caught me by surprise and is a great example of Early Access done right. I paid the $9.99 awhile ago and I felt it was completely worth it, and after the frequent updates and improvements, it definitely continues to be worth the money. While I do think the UI needs to be cleaned up a little and the story could be fleshed out more, NEO Scavenger is still a great game. From the crafting that is more than just there because a ton of games are including it, to the way it draws you in for one more turn, and then another, and then maybe another hour goes by, I couldn't say enough good things. There are some flaws and it isn't for everyone, but check out the demo and support a developer that does Early Access right. I've so far put nearly 30 hours into NEO Scavenger and I'll definitely be adding to that number as time goes on

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								     You can look around the review pages for this game and see a sea of "recommend" posts, thats for good reason, and I will get to that. First however, I would like to try and define what NEO Scavenger is, though that may be difficult.      NEO Scav is a survival game in its simplest form but the title of "Survival" doesn't do it justice. I would like to define it as a "Turn based RPG", but that too doesn't quite fit the bill. "Sandbox"? no, not that either . Now I'm not saying that all of these traits and aspects are not included in NEO Scav, but each one does not define it well alone. The only thing I can think to do is paste all of them together (using medium string and a sharp edge) making it a Sandbox Survival Turn Based Role Playing Game (a SSTBRPG), now all we have to do is throw a H in front of that acronym for "Hardcore" and its shaping up to be a decent genre description, a bit of a mouthful though.      Not that (H)SSTBRPG's really exist (that I know of aside from a few indie titles scattered about the web) as a gaming norm, just kind of an acronym I made up on the spot, but the idea isn't a norm. Why is that? The only answer I could think of was that it is too much of a risk for large companies to make a game like that, one that would truly test a person's ability to survive in the wilderness  and deal with day to day threats like hunger, thirst, sleep, and warmth. I don't know if that's true or not, and looking at the amount of people who play games like NEO Scav, I can't see how that theory could hold together. I'm getting off track. ------------------------------------------------------------------------------------     NEO Scavenger is created (to my knowledge) by one person, Daniel Fedor. That alone when looking at the game is an amazing feat, especially considering how in depth NEO Scav truly is. Whether its crafting or just scavenging there is plenty of things for you to make or find.      The first day is the hardest, you wake up in an odd place with something scratching at the door (I won't go into detail as, well... Spoilers) , but you immediately have to escape. Using skills to selected at the start, a set of four with the ability to add more at the cost of negative traits, you venture out into the world.      You walk out into the sunlight of the world, its dawn,  its cold, and you don't have much in the way of clothing save a hospital gown. Immediately you're struck with a problem, find clothing or die of hypothermia. This is what kills most new survivors, and it took me a while (and a few protagonist deaths) to find my rhythm. This first day is brutal, but once it's over, a whole new day begins.       Now you're warm-ish, but the previous days exertions have caused you to grow quite thirsty. You see that there's a water source nearby, a river, but you don't know if the water is safe to drink. You have no method of checking if its "infected" or if its "sterile" but  you don't have the luxury of waiting. This is something that kills off a lot of the players that make it past day one. Let's say you were lucky, and now you're no longer thirsty, and you didn't manage to acquire some form of disease or infection, now what.      By this time you're starting to feel a little hungry, while scavenging you manage to find a couple of mushrooms and some berries, but without the proper skill (which you can choose at the start of the game, it's called "Botany") you can't tell if these are poisonous or not.  You pick them up all the same, if it comes to it, you might have to take the chance.      But whats that on the horizon, it looks like another scavenger is none too pleased with you stealing his supplies (or for any myriad of other reasons), and now he wants you dead. You can't escape, you have to fight. You pick up a large nearby stick and prepare to defend yourself.      The fight is frantic, messy, and results in both parties getting pretty bruised up, but eventually the other scavenger retreats from battle, leaving you to treat your wounds...     The point is that NEO Scavenger is relentless in its urge to kill you, but it's not like you can't combat this. You can cover you're tracks so that enemies have a harder time following you, you can hide in urban areas and ambush scavengers to steal their stuff, you can apply bandages to your wounds and take pain pills to deal with blood loss and manage the amount of pain your character is in. All the while traveling for some far off goal. And there is SO much more, and even more to be added I'm sure. -----------------------------------------------------------------------------------     In short try the demo, it's a pretty accurate but  slimmed down version of how the game plays out, if you like it, buy it... you can't go wrong. The creator is pretty active in the forums, discussing current game bugs and ideas with the community, both here on steam, as well as on his site at Blue Bottle Games.  Take care, good luck surviving, and hopefully this was helpful. P.Kindred XIII

content:

Early Access Review
								Neo scavanger Is a awsome game period, Dont let the screen shots or videos fool you this game is great its crazy in depth and the plot is tried and true, the game is so amazing that I could cut down a tree limb and combine it with a tarp I had found to make a lean to, or take a pot and fire to boil my water to make it safe to drink, These are just a small sample of the variety of things you can create, it almost feels like if you can think it you can do it, Very few games other than project zomboid (also an amazing game) seem to be able to give you this sense of depth, The game is played by reading text and moving your character in a grid overworld kinda like final fantasy tactics, I will admit from screenshots I said this game will suck and its not for me....Boy was I wrong just get the demo play it and Im sure you will buy it, This is the only game I have ever played that I killed a man just for his left boot, This game is hard it wants you to die, but each time you do you learn from it and the next time you will go a little farther this style of gameplay is very rewarding do yourself a favor and pick up neo scavanger, In its current early access state I give it a 9/10 amazing.
