number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								The unique style of NEO Scavenger is not that unique as they want you to believe. It's very reminiscient of the original point and click games such as Fallout and Baldur's Gate with even similar typed "cells" you interact with. Now, that's not necessarily a bad thing. In this case it works great for the way the game wants you to play. Finding resources and survival are obviously key to this type of game and they don't fail on that note.However, the combat seems way too strange. Albiet, if you have a weapon (melee or ranged) the fights are much easier to succeed; my encounters with fights early game with no weapons lead in instant failure. I don't know many people in an apocalyptic setting that can take getting punched, tackled, kicked, and mercilessly harrassed for very long. Yet the survivors you fight, have exceptional durability. You can kick a person 10+ times on the ground and they still somehow manage to stand up, punch you and break your shoulderblade. After a 12 minute fight with the first random stranger outside ends, I freeze to death and all of that was a waste of nothing. I understand this game is not to be taken lightly and stroll through it, but I haven't made it far past the first main objective. I have frozen to death at least eight or so times because of how the world is roughly randomized. Sometimes you're lucky and fight resources to keep you alive and buildings to sleep in so you can make it there, but other times, you will freeze to death before you can find a shack. No matter how unsettling this sounds, I truly have been enjoying myself everytime I play. Simply because the story has already captivated me into wanting to hear more on the story. As well as enjoying the game, minus the few listed, I have had no complications with playing this game and I'm excited to see any possible additions and hoping for better luck in my coming ventures.

								God damn, there are so many ways to die in this game. IT IS HARSH. Acting reckless always gets you killed, not having a game plan will often result in dying whether by a bandit or being poisoned by some bad water. When you get this game, don't expect the odds to ever be in your favor, (unless you're fighting melon heads). BUT, it is still pretty fun, I often have youtube in the backround listening to music, because there is not music yet in this game. Also, often I'm not really into turn based games, but this caught my attention, and I actually like it! The combat is very unique and awesome and real, and often if you choose different traits in your character, and you have different weapons, and different enemys to face, so each time you play the experience is different, considering also the map is mostly randomly generated, (story bits stay the same). So, overall I'd give this a good seven, because, despite all that, the game isn't very engaging, it's kinda hard for you to get hooked and play for hours straight because of how hard it is. But, keep in mind, this is just my opinion! And the game  is in Alpha, but a good alpha. I hope I helped!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Very much enjoyed this game and will likely play it some more. I haven't even gotten very far so far, just under 5 days of survival I believe. Much like FTL (Faster Than Light) you will find this game gives the player a number of significant choices in a world that is generated differently each time with events equally varied and random. The game has it's flaws, to be sure. And without using much of a guide thus far I still occasionally get confused or am unsure as to how some mechanic works. It has occurred once that I was in a fight I believed I was winning when all of a sudden my equipment had disappeared and I was out of battle finding myself thinking to the game "I'm sure you're right, but why?". All in all, the game has many possibilities to make it immersive, there are a few things to be improved on, a few minor bugs and a learning curve if you want to make your way far. But all in all, I would say this is great for a player looking for a good survival game. Much like FTL, this game isn't made for you to be the hero, or in your favor like other games where you are central to the plot. You exist on it's terms, you can't run around being all-mighty.I would also like to add that this game has static graphics to accommodate the text/UI based game so don't expect anything aesthetically amazing. The graphics accomplish what they need to accomplish, they will make the world feel complete, but not 'beautiful', and to be frank that's fine. It suits what the game is. With that said, I would also like to add that the text portions are very well written in my opinion and the events I have encountered thus far have been incredibly interesting.This game isn't for everyone. If you aren't interested in survival games I wouldn't recommend it, nor if you are looking for a beautiful game. If you believe you have the imagination however or desire to see how you'd fare in a survival game I would definitely suggest looking into the game a bit further and possibly throwing out the $10 to buy into the game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								I for one am a very big fanatic of hardcore survival games such as this one, but had been surprised when I first started playing. I have been playing "hardcore" games for years, now. This game brings on a new definition for the word. This game is immerciful, harsh, and unforgiving. One wrong move and you could have your entire life come crashing down. You should never expect to live longer than past the night when playing this game. At first, you'll likely only live about a few hours, if not a day or two. After a while, you'll start discovering recipes, finding equipment, and even special places that do/don't have much to do with the story, such as Zom Zom's. Along the paths you take, you will have opportunities to help people, scavenge for resources, and even get in a fight or two. The entire game is ectremely difficult and is not something to be played leisurely. I do have one problem with the game, though, and that's the constant dying by "Acute bleeding in the lungs." It's almost become the new "Arrow in the knee", which can also happen, making your experience feel somewhat ironic at times. But, back to the "Acute bleeding in the lungs", I find that it happens much too often, making the game feel somewhat less serious. Sure, it only happens after getting whacked in the chest and stomach repeatedly, but you could imagine how annoying it would be to see that it's the only reason you die, half of the time. I would reccomend this game to any person interested in a new type of survival game. A word of warning, though; don't take off your talisman!

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								Don't let the boardgame hex look and turn-based gameplay fool you: This is a complex survival simulation, one of the best I've played and almost certainly the best on Steam. Even in early access, the game is in a completely playable and mature state, a notable contrast to the buggy, imbalanced status of almost every game available in this genre.The drag/drop crafting system is intuitive yet almost too simple, at once the game's greatest asset and biggest barrier to sinking too much time into it. A few minor ease of use tweaks would go a long way. Still, conceptually, this is the kind of system RPGs need to return to, especially outside of the roguelike/survival setting. The far less accessible UnReal World is the only game I can think of that compares. This game drops a lot of the old-school roguelike cruft in a positive way (usually that's a bad thing!), so I would honestly recommend this to anybody interested in this sort of game first.

								First time ever writing a review.. Needless to say I'm pretty stoked about NEO Scavenger. I had stopped playing a while because the character I'd gotten good gear with got sick and died or something.. but I recently picked this back up and I have to say I'm impressed with the additions that have been made. Overall the game itself is frustrating, but not in  a bad way. You're constantly being challenged with the goal of survival. Right from the beginning the game throws this DogMan creature at you and you have several different ways to play out the encounter. What surprised me most was the wraith like being that popped up out of nowhere when I made it to the city, silly ol' me thought I could take a whack at him with a crowbar, Mr. Wraith had other ideas. I died... rightfully so. All in all... I think NEO Scavenger was a good purchase, if you aren't sure don't shy away from that demo, it'll give you a good idea what this game is all about,Also.. NEW SHOES!

content:
Posted: February 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								The combat is turn based, but feels organic and possesses a gritty realism that is unparalleled. The first few fights are always the worst until your last. You take turns tackling other survivors to the groud, kicking while they're down, dragging and scraping and brutally beating one another with whatever wrench or saucepan or tree limb that is at hand until one of you begs for mercy, but only after sustaining a broken arm and internal bleeding. On the other hand, simply waving a gun and shouting is usually enough to scare off scavangers, nevermind you don't have any bullets because they don't need to know that. When a turn based system can get your heart pounding, something is being done right.

								This game looks and is low-tech, with alot of difficulty for new players. (suggest you get the demo first). number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really like Neo Scavenger. That's why there will be a long, LONG review on it. To Start, in even a short time of five hours, this game has left a great impression on me, from death to art style to dialogues... It's brilliant to begin with.Gameplay: You wake up in the middle of Michigan in some sort of year, in which humanity is back to the dark ages. Heal yourself, fight, scavenge, explore, talk, DAMN. And more. Every choice is better then Mass Effect's Endings and choices. DAAAAMN. 10/10Story/Quests: Survive in the apocalypse, find out who you are, DUN DUN DUN! Kinda cliche, but I will give the quests and random encounters credit. 7/10Dialogues: Pretty long, and most of the lore is delivered through it, which was somewhat of a let-down. However, the dialogue was good. I'll shame it for it's lack of a Dialogue Tree thus far. 7/10AI: The AI was great. Enemies were either cowards or knew how to fight, and their AI reflected that. With the combat system, it sets up a difficulty of COMPLEXITY, and that's either really good or bad game design. Here, it's done great. 8/10World Design: Semi-Dynamic, beautifully designed, randomly generated. It's luck, but damn good luck. 9/10Graphics: The game is set up in a 32-bit art style (I believe?), and the graphics look promising. Some shots of the world are detailed, even with 32 pixels. This game would have great graphics back in the 32-bit era, and good indie graphics. 8/10Sound: Haha. None. 0/10Music: There is a death track, thus far. Nothing special. 4/10The verdict for NEO Scavenger is an 8.75/10. It delivers well, and it's promising, even for late Early Access. Some small tweaks, and this could easily go over a 9.DayZ Review Gimmick: "Slept in an office, robbed and left with my plastic bag. 8.75/10, would sleep again."

content:

								Well, if you're into games like FTL, or df in the way you pretty much lose no matter what, this is your game! GAMEPLAY:In every way its a flash game, as most of us gamers believe, flash games suck for the most part. Though, this game is interesting and enjoyable. There are wolfdogs(kind of like a warewolf but dog instead....first encouter creature) and melonheads(science experiments gone wrong?), then you have good old raiders and looters. The AI in this game is really good! It tracks you(every time you move you have tracks layed down, and the AI can/will follow them if you dont hide them. There are skills that allow you to scavenge better, like lock picking. You can build things with machanic, etc. There is a large crafting system, vehicals to pull/push your stuff around(aka sleds, shopping carts.) So, all in all if you're like me, meaning you pinch every penny and get at least 20+hrs from every game, then this is most likely for you. 10/10 would buy.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I heard about this game from a friend and decided to play the demo to see how I felt. About two hours passed and I purchased the actual game, to spend another two or three hours playing the balls off of it.At first a first look I was unsure about the action events (fights, encounters etc.) seeing as it was primarily text and seemed like it would be a little dull. I was very wrong, while yes the action events are just text along with some other info (character portraits, conditions and so on), it doesn't detract from the intensity at all. If anything imagining what is happening as it's described to you makes the whole fight even more tense.I think the most appealing thing about this game is how realistic it is. You can (and will) die in so many different ways, it's fantastic! You can be beaten to death, bleed out, get poisoned, mauled, shot, etc. But what I love is how indirect it is. You can go into a forest and eat some berries, a few turns later you get some pop up text informing you that your character is vomiting. What caused that? Was it the berries? The dirty bandage giving you an infection? The water from the lake? Along with hunger, thrist, sleep deprivation, temperature and the horde of melonheads closing in the game becomes very stressful. But in the best possible way.Besides the many ways to die, the scavenging is top notch. Far better than say Fallout for the sake of argument, where you gather stuff for a while and then you're good till end game. In NEO Scavenger you need to keep scavenging to survive and you will not find guns in every house, or food in every cabin. Chances are you'll die before ever using a gun, but when you have one with the right ammo, you feel worried about using it in case it's wasted. This combined with the crafting and character skills to open up new options, makes each playthrough very different.  The best part is the game isn't even done yet, so new features are being added to make this experience even better. So if you're reading this right now and you're still unsure I really reccommend you at least try the demo. I think this game is fantastic and would really sing it's praises to anyone who's looking for a challenging and realistic survival game.  I'd give it a solid 8/10 so far, would be swarmed by melonheads again.

												Despite some of the more fantastic elements of the game, such as the inclusion of monsters from urban legend, such as the Michigan dog man and the Enfield horror, this is one of the more realistic survival experiences I've seen.  most of the time, the reasons why I died had more to do with the enviroment, freezing to death especially, but also poisoning, disease, nd starvation.  aas for the combat, it also has a more realistic feel, with some fights dragging on for several minutes as you get chased through the woods, while even weaker weapons can easily cause enemies to bleed out with good strikes.  sometimes i wish certain enemy types would be more adaptive, with most raiders attacking on sight and most people running away as soon as you spot them once you get good equipment, it still a really good game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								Permadeath has never been so fun!It's so hard to find a good survival game that doesn't feature hordes of the undead - often in place of more creative challenges to, well, staying alive. Similarly, it's the rare title that does anything very well at all for less than $10 these days. NEO Scavenger fits both bills and still has more to come (I guess... I haven't noticed many bugs and I think I've progressed a fair distance). You'll probably need the wiki to help you get started, if only because you have to get the hang of some of the craftable items. I played the demo for about forty-five minutes before grabbing the full version and only had two or three things I'd count as bugs:1) My save data was inexplicably lost once, but I didn't mind starting over2) It seems to me that there's really only one way to start with any decent chance but that's not necessarily going to stay true in the final version (and I could be wrong - there's a decent amount of randomness with each play)3) Sometimes you setup a camp site and it disappears later, sometimes re-appearing on a later visit to that hexNone of these, for me, are game-breakers because I'm not playing NEO Scavenger to win - I'm playing to -survive-. This means battling cold weather, raiders and dogmen, hunger, thirst, fatigue, and the dangers of exploring/scavenging ruined buildings that might collapse on you at any moment. I simply include most of the bugs along with the other dangers and keep on truckin' (or start a new game). I highly recommend that anyone looking to play a game that focuses on those things as NEO Scavenger really does it well. Happy Gaming!

Early Access Review
								This  game is amazing. It has endless replayability and there is so much to do and make. The developers obviously put alot of hard work and thought into this game and it paid off. The story is the same but how you complete it differs. While as great as this game is, I do not reccomend it to people who have little patience, because this game can be incredibly frusterating. It is very hard to survive and once you die that's it. No take-backs or nothing, so it's crucial to manage your stats and to use your heads when events happen. NeoScavenger is easy to learn with simple controls, and isn't too hard on your computer (aka, even the crappiest of computers should be able to run this pretty well). I seriously reccomend it, if you're looking into buying this game, just stop reading reviews now and buy it. You wont be disappointed.

content:
Posted: December 20, 2014
												This is an engrossing survival game that sloooowly becomes easier as you learn to do basic actions to ensure your survival...like sterilizing water and crafting a sharp-stick spear.  If you die in the game you must restart...unless you have manually copied a save game (nsSGv1.sol) to another folder.  In fact it is nearly impossible to progress without this crutch.  The game is very fun at first but once you have learned to survive for long periods you realize there is little other content.  There are some simple "quests" but mostly it is the same thing over and over.  I liked the game very much and played for more than 30 hours.   Well worth the $10-$15 price.  Can't figure out how to give a numerical rating but it would be 7.5.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 21, 2014
												Possibly the best survival game I've ever played. I was very hesitant to purchase this particular game after my experience with Don't Starve. Although I did enjoy the gameply of Don't Starve, I feel no need to come back to that game, because even with it's rogue-like elements, it feels like the same experience every time. This is something I feel NEO Scavenger did much better. The skill system has so many good choices, that no particular set feels like the "best" way to play the game. It simply comes down to which way you actually want to play your current playthrough.The other thing NEO Scavenger did particularly well is entry to the game itself. Without limiting the player's choices, the developers found a way to keep the game simple enough at the start that you wouldn't get lost in the incredibly complex mechanics until you actually need to use the particular rules of the game. By starting you with noting to survive the cold weather, you're forced to learn how to utilize the scavenge mechanic, which is the most important decision of the game. If more games that were this complex had openings like this one, I feel more people could explore the depths of these incredible games.Even though it's clearly done on a budget, the art of the game is very well chosen. I found it easy to destinguish between the different items that I scavenged, and I rarely felt confused by the sprites that were on screen.Even though the story itself isn't the big draw to the game itself, it's very well written. I found myself genuinely caring about my character and even being sympathetic to some of the people i encountered. These characters were made so well that I genuinely found myself thinking if I really needed to kill the people I came across. Even though it's clearly "every man for himself", the difficulty of recovering from fights and the chance of my having to drop my cart and run made each encounter a very difficult choice.This is quickly becoming one of my favorite titles that I found on steam.

												After spending an in-game day or two barely subsisting on squirrels, I spotted a military looking guy near my camp. I hid and spied on him, he hadn't seen me. I creeped up behind him and managed to get the jump on him with my crowbar. He went down like a sack of potatoes and now all his shiny army gear was mine. I am the master of the wasteland!I then spent the next 3 days being relentlessly tracked and hunted by his 2 army buddies who eventually caught up to me, shot me in the gut, stripped all my gear and left me to bleed out :(10/10, incredibly detailed survival simulator randomly generated for a different playthrough every time. Only issue is some slight UI clunkiness.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 30, 2014
												A surprisingly deep game about amnesia and survival in a harsh, apocalyptic themed world. Manage food, hunger, body temperature, and injuries and disease while you try to navigate the world avoiding fearsome monsters and people alike. Find the most secure campsite you can and hope that nothing gets the jump on you while you sleep (crafting can help alleviate this issue), encounter different events around the world which will make the world you're inhabiting seem strange, engage in a very deep combat system which has many types of injuries and conditions as well as ways to go about combat, and ultimately try and figure out who 'you' are.In case barely surviving through the mass consumation of ketchup packets isn't your thing, it's the only game I've ever played where I got into combat wielding a bag of potato chips and pulling an orange toboggan behind me, or after the stars aligned punched somebody so hard in the chest that they died of acute bleeding after one hit.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												One of my favorite rougelike games in recent memory. I actually really enjoyed learning all the mechanics of survival, and going from only being able to survive for less than a day reliabily to learning how to survive for days and weeks on end was really rewarding.I must have spent 30 hours learning the systems, and around 2-3 hours for a winning run. I only wish that there was more content: it felt like the game was only just getting started by the time I had won. Then again, I guess it does make sense to end the game when you're getting a run to the point where you're pretty self sufficiant. It could get a bit boring otherwise.

												All-righty, nothing like waking up from a nice long cryo slumber with nothing but a hospital gown, a wrist-Band, and a 1970's medallion to your name. Then immediately being assailed by a cross between Cujo and Hulk Hogan, which causes you to flee for your life into the wastelands  of Detroit...(Which oddly enough is a lot like present day Detroit). It is all good for a while drink a little scavenged H2O and some berries ( I suggest the Botany Skill ). Ahh yes you can feel the rumble in your tunny as the unfiltered and tainted water begins to take it's toll. Soon you are crapping blood and running for your life to find the nearest tree so you can prolapse your♥♥♥♥♥♥, congratulations in the not so distant future amoebic dysentery is alive and well . After crapping yourself into the who's who book of The Screaming Squats, you realize you are now suffering from hypothermia...but it is ok you can pretty much scavenge , salvage, and construct most anything. That is of course if the Melon-Heads, and Bad Mutha do not find you and make you "Squeell Like a Big Boy! CAUSE YOU SURE DO GOTS A PERTTY MOUTH!". MAYBE YOU LOOSE IT AND AXE MURDER THE WHOLE LOT OF THEM WHILE THEY SLEEP...!Just do not eat them, eating human meat is for Punks...dont be a Punk, harvest a berry or eat a shroom....then start beating feat again...Just understand you are gona die...maybe you'll freeze or starve, or crap yourself to death, get eaten, electrocuted....who knows,but it will happen....But it is OK, because this is one fun as hell game...It will not try to dazzle you with BS, no super flashy graphics to hide the fact that it sux more than a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ named Eureka..No, see because if you took this game from Samuel L Jackson and dropped it in a bag of other games, and then same told you to give him his Sh*% back and you asked which one was his...Sam would tell you...It is the game that has Bad Mutha f%$#$% written on it. Listen if you have 15 or so bucks do yourself a favor and buy this game, buy it play it and then watch your character die horribly and love enjoy it.

												The first thing you have to know about NEO Scavenger:You will die. A lot. I was told there is a fabled ending to the game but I have yet to see it. That said, I adore this game. Wait for a sale if you can, but if not, I'd buy this again for 15 bucks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I have discovered my true calling as a hobo, fighting off feral dogs to scavenge post-apocalyptic ruins for anything remotely valuable.This game is quite good. It's actually very short, which is probably a good thing because it's so difficult. However, despite the amount of random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that seems to kill you in this game, I never had a death where that I couldn't see why it was my fault. The world is extremely harsh, but you'll mostly find out about the stuff that kills you early in the game, or it's common sense, so you won't get to the endgame only to be insta-killed unless YOU do something stupid. Just be aware that the minute you DO do anything stupid, you will probably die. This, together with the core gameplay around surviving, is what kept me coming back to the game, even after ragequitting in frustration and deciding to never play it again. The different systems around survival -health, scavenging, combat, crafting, character creation, bartering, and inventory - work together extremely well. I have a weakness for survival and sandbox games, especially rogue-like survival games, but I'm also very harsh on them. I have a lot of problems with games like Minecraft, Rust, Ark, Terraria, DayZ and more. NEO Scavenger has been the perfect survival experience for me though. It's not something to spend hundreds of hours on, no. Based on my playtime so far and the playtime of other reviewers, 70ish hours seems to be the cap before interest dives. That's when I felt like I had thoroughly learned how the game worked. What makes this an engaging experience is going from knowing nothing about the game to being able to take on any challenge it thows at you. Amazingly, it succeeds in being an experience both fantastic and realistic.It's not perfect, of course. The story events and random events have some problems, but even though these choose-your-own-adventure style events can kill you, they're actually surprisingly lenient compared to the core mechanics of the game. You usually have to screw up pretty bad to get killed, and most frequently you just get a slap on the hand if you didn't choose exactly the right path through event. Since I died so much outside of the events, it was pretty fun to see how different paths and different character builds affected the outcome. Other than that, I personally couldn't care about the story and events very much. It's interesting, moderately good quality, and original. I normally love narrative and world-building in games, but in NEO Scavenger it took the backseat to the core gameplay. The only negative thing I can say about that is it could just use MORE. The art style, while flat, is exactly what it needs to be for the game, but everything definitely looks the same after only an hour or two. If there were a few more hex-types and some variation in textures, and especially if there was some physical depth, as in changes in elevation, to the terrain, it would be much more visually interesting. The item count is decent, but if there was just a bit more customization possible it would be awesome, and then every single npc wouldn't look identical. The map is actually quite large, and it can take a long time to get across it when you're looting everything that's even slightly lootable and fending off all manner of dangers along the way, but it could really use a few more unique locations with events tied to them, even though I said that's not what I'm here for. The character building is great: it really does feel like original Fallout and it totally determines what you can do and how you play, but for a system so deep it just feels so small. The world NEO Scavenger takes place in is very interesting, but outside of vague newspaper articles there's not actually all that much to explain it all. With a more cohesive and expansive lore, I could really get into this world. The story, like I said, is very short, and I frankly don't care that much about it; it's good enough for me. But it does have this interesting problem that unless you explore everything you can easily "complete" the story in just two "quests". It's pretty hard to tell what kind of story NEO Scavenger wants to tell, and how. I don't think it needs to be longer. With multiple paths and endings and the difficulty of the game it benefits from being short. But it does need a few more storytelling mechanics, and probably a better, more dense distribution of the story throughout the gameplay. As is, you play the core game and progress for a long while, and then you get a big chunk of wall-of-text story.All in all, if you want a solid survival role-playing game, this is what you want. I think that for the type of people who enjoy this game you can expect as much as 70 hours of extremely engaging time with this game, which is definitely worth $15. Enjoy!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Despite its aged graphics and less than perfect UI this is a real gem of a post apocalyptic survival game. It can be truly unforgiving, but that to me was one of the things that drew me into the world of NEO Scavenger. The survival aspect is a lot more engaging to me than most other survival type games I've played, and you quickly learn to pick your battles very carefully. Just like in reality, a single wound can end up killing you if you're careless and don't have access to modern medicine, and nature itself can be equally lethal. This is something I've found to be missing from most other survival games. The story is fairly interesting as well, but some of the choice based encounters are a bit harsh. And losing a character that survived for a long time in one of those is rarely fun. Still, the game kept drawing me back in until I had beaten it, and I'm looking forward to what the developer has in store for us next.If you want a challenge, love the roguelike aspect of dead is dead in a post apocalyptic setting and can look past the graphics then you can't really go wrong with this game.

												Highly recomended, this game lets you do a lot that, at surface level it does not apper that it would be deep enough to allow.Example: I had just reached a little shack in the woods, I was a little low on provisions, so I desided to camp there for a little while so i could try to find water and food. While I was there two looters with guns came by and tryed to steal my stuff. I, naturaly, tryed to stop them. After all that was all my stuff. They shot me a couple of times, and while a was sitting on the floor looseing blood they made off with my backpack full of stuff and most of my medical equipment. I dressed my wounds as best I could, and went to get some water and something to eat. I was banged up, but I would live. Then as i was headed back to my shack, I eat some poisonous berries and died.If you think that sounds frustrating, it was, but that is not the games fault, it was mine. You learn from your mistakes and you get better, could not recomend this game any more than I am right now, buy it.

												You wake up from a cryo sleep.You look around and suddenly you're attaked by a massive hairy werewolf like creature.What do you do?Do you run out the window like a coward? Do you use your nerd skills to hack the door to shut? Do you use your medical prowess to unfreeze another cryo sleeper and use him as a live bait?If you are like me you'll choose secret option 4: Beat the living daylights out of it, video record the beating and then procede to skin him and run around Post-Apocalyptic Michigan wearing his flayed hide for as long as you can."As long as you can" = Death by cholera. Day 3 (but maybe you'll have better luck!)Pretty much Oregon Trail meets the Walking Dead, this Post Apocalyptic romp will have you dying millions of times but trust me, you'll learn to love it (in a non-masochistic way, of course. Lets keep things PG) Perfect game for people who like survival games. Only down side was the poorly directed objectives, but hey, it's a survival game not an rpg, SURVIVE is enough of a goal for me.Happy hunting.P.S. Nevereverever take off that amulet around your neck unless you want a cool way to comit suicide. Trust me. I know things.

												In the tradition of old-school HARD video games, NEO Scavenger is a titanic struggle of one man against the environment.  Craft, sneak, and fight your way to survival, while unlocking a multi-part storyline shockingly deep for such a 16bit game. Pros:Turn Based Gameplay Low requirementsDeep and Immersive Storyline and World-LoreDelicious MeatFaction SystemLegendary 3-Dog-Moon ShirtCons:CholeraLack of Craftable Headwear/FootwearUnused SlotsSomewhat Shallow ChargenWTB Multi-Player ExperienceNo Dog-TamingLack of Build/Fortify/Expand mechanics.

												Really unique gameplay. Fun post-apocalyptic setting with creative turn based combat and a cool selection of items and crafting. Although the name says it right there, it's fun to scavenge things.The world is neat, but the major story points are a little disjointed and seem out of place. content:
Posted: July 10, 2015
												This game is a true survival game, and follows the rouglike forumular very well, and chances are you will not survive youre first play though. Although once you get though the game and understand what you must do to survive it can become very metagamey, you will eventualy pick a particular path every play though because its "right" and there are some instances in some encounters that will kill you that make no sence, like getting eaten by 'the grudge' monster in the assylum. but that said there are some elements of common sence that can be followed though some of the other encounters its very aparent after reaching the main city that the game maker just wanted to wrap up the game as quickly as he could, and it dose not really end with any kind of real resolve. Some time the Random encounters toy with the part of you that wants to be a wasteland hero instilled in us by games like fallout, only to flip you the middle finger and remind you that you are very human and weak and vulnerable and something bad happening to you as a result. Some of the writing could be improved being a bit more decriptive, but it captures the feeling of Michagan Hobo cannibal shoe Salesman very well.

												I love love love this game. It is fun,hard,and no matter what,you are GOING TO DIE.the only downside is the new ability selecter.What you used to have:4 free slots for being human.extra slots for you to pick weaknesses,yet have some strengths to balance it.What you have now:The stupidest selecting system ever,they limit your ability to make your character SO badly. now you have 15 ability points,and the weaknesses add to your ability points. the downside? 												When I'm tired from working and my brain is having  a hard time kicking into gear in more intense games, Neo Scavenger foots the bill.Addictively fun. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 23, 2015
												This game drops you right into conflict: you wake up amnesiac, barefoot, naked, with a hungry wolf-thing in the adjacent room of a cryogenic facility.The first second of the game is pretty much the last time you won't be desperately hungry, thirsty, hypothermic, exhausted, bleeding out, diseased, hunted down, or some gruesome mix of these things.From there, the game revolves around challenging resource management as you explore a large hex-titled world looking for supplies and answers.Do you leave behind the squirrel-trap or the cleaver?Do you carry the sleeping bag or the rifle with 5 bullets?Do you risk alerting the raiders nearby with a bonfire or do you let the cold weather grip you a bit tighter for another sleepless night?Do you eat the rancid meat or do you risk a fist-fight with another looter to see if they have food?Do you slowly drag their corpse to the woods to cook their flesh or do you press onwards into the fog of war?Do you run to your next destination and get there in a day or do you silently sneak there and get there in three?Until NEO Scavenger, I had no idea a turn-based hex-tiled game could compel such a convincing post-apocalyptic desperation.My advice to you is to just jump in and hang in there until you've spent a couple hours. To be honest, I didn't even like the game at first until I'd suffered about ten deaths or so. Then I began to understand and get a glimpse of what the game had to offer. Like when I let a bandit limp away from a fight only for him to come back five turns later to kill me in my sleep with the cleaver I left behind at a salvage site a few tiles away.It also sometimes feels like you aren't making any progress since it's so easy to die (permadeath), but soon you realize that you're surviving a little longer every attempt - 3 days, 5 days, 1 week, 2 weeks. And the game just gets better and better as you begin to master it. What used to seem like a basic combat system turns out to be a nuanced one. What used to seem like a pointless skill/ability becomes your favorite. etc.My only complaint is that the UI is sometimes a bit tedious. For example, having to put down the sleeping bag every night and remember to pick it back up in the morning. Or doing the same 10-mouseclick dance with the crafting system to chop wood, light a fire, cook meat, and then eat the meat. But then again, you're usually so happy to find meat that 10 or so clicks is a small price to pay.Also, due to the crafting system UI, it's tedious to answer the question: "What can I craft with the things I currently have in my inventory?" As I accumulate items, I often find myself flipping through my recipes to see if I can make anything useful, only to do it again in five turns to see if anything changed. The game would benefit from a quick-view of "Here are the items you can currently craft" with the ability to click those items to instantly make them.However, the grid-based inventory management system is a fun minigame in itself. It really is addictive to answer questions like "Should I put the pistol with zero bullets in my pocket or should I fill my pocket with these gummy bears?" - Oh wait, your worn-out pants are going to disintegrate in about five turns, but you'll probably get hunted down by a mutant wolf before you have to deal with that.Good luck!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 5, 2016
												Raw, Challenging, Unforgiving and ultimately a test of will. You must survive in a harsh environment against realistic conditions and wounds in what appears to be a post apocolyptic world. Every wound could become your last as you struggle to find equipment to help push you forward. Balance your traits to your advantage and use them as your life depends on it.This seemingly simple game will prove a true challenge as even the most seasoned veteren can find himself in an untimely end as the environment and its stalkers barrage you with attacks from bitter cold, poisoned food to cannibalistic warriors hell bent on your life. Every night could be your last as survival is truly of the fittest.This game pushes you to your limits as you use your wits to make every choice from what you carry, to how you fight, and how you treat that gashed leg and shattered ribs.Can you survive?As someone who truly loves a true raw environment where the details count in the mechanics of the game, I have to give this a high score. It's truly one of the few of its kind out there and it does it excellently. I highly recommend this game!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Despite its aged graphics and less than perfect UI this is a real gem of a post apocalyptic survival game. It can be truly unforgiving, but that to me was one of the things that drew me into the world of NEO Scavenger. The survival aspect is a lot more engaging to me than most other survival type games I've played, and you quickly learn to pick your battles very carefully. Just like in reality, a single wound can end up killing you if you're careless and don't have access to modern medicine, and nature itself can be equally lethal. This is something I've found to be missing from most other survival games. The story is fairly interesting as well, but some of the choice based encounters are a bit harsh. And losing a character that survived for a long time in one of those is rarely fun. Still, the game kept drawing me back in until I had beaten it, and I'm looking forward to what the developer has in store for us next.If you want a challenge, love the roguelike aspect of dead is dead in a post apocalyptic setting and can look past the graphics then you can't really go wrong with this game.

												Probably one of the best if not best survival games I've ever played.I played the demo for a few months on Blue Bottle Games site and I fell in love with it, I spent hours playing, crafting, getting as far as I could then starting all over again. 								This is a very interesting game with great looking art, an AMAZING system for just about everything, and it's also the only game I have ever even heard of where you can die from cholera, blue rot, being gored to death by a robotic saber tooth tiger, being chopped to bits by a robot, acute bleeding in the lungs, traumatic head injury, and numerous other diseases and medical conditions. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a post apocylipic survival game, Neo Scavenger serves as a (probably) pleasent diversion from the typical zombie survival genre. In this game you are faced not only enemies from both the earth and beyond, but also with realistic factors to your person that may prove your undoing if neglected, and you are also faced with perma death.Combat in this game makes up with it's lack of action with it's in depth desicion system that controls how you approach situations, which also comes to play in miscelanious events that fall outside of regular gameplay. These 'events' will grant you with better outcomes if you select the right perks for your character at the beginning the game. Select the wrong ones during character creation, however, then you might as well let the dogmen (not to be confused with werewolves) eat you where you stand.The cruel realism of the game forces you to think, making this game fun to play and giving it it's strategic element. And now that modding is becoming available, I personally cannot wait for all the crazy - or scary - ideas the comunity can grant for this game!

content:
Posted: March 1, 2015
 Survival done right NEO Scavenger is another survival game set in a post-apocalyptic scenario where your mission is to, you guessed it, survive. Lately I've noticed that many games of this genre are, for the most part, shallow and very boring. Whether it's the oversaturation or my lack of interest, but I just haven't been able to find a good realistic survival game to spark my interest. But then comes Blue Bottle Games and gives us this fantastic, well-thought-out RPG that I just can't stop playing.The gameplay is probably my favorite part about it, because it involves turn-based strategy, the best kind of strategy that fits these types of games so well. You will cautiously think about every next move you make. The style is similar to games such as Wasteland or S.T.A.L.K.E.R. but the difficulty resembles that of a Dark Souls game.I think it speaks volumes when an indie game does a much better job at creating a world so dark and brutal that will make you dread every moment you explore it than most AAA titles with their overblown visuals and lack of originality. Just to make it clear, this one of the best survival simulations that you can experience, this game does not favor sloppiness, you will die until you learn how to survive the wasteland.HIGHLY RECOMMENDED! 10 shoes/10

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 8, 2015
												Neo Scavenger is a fantastic indie turn-based, survival, strategy, roguelike game played on a hex map. The game is very punishing and largely based apon RNG but also requires a lot of pre-planning strategy and skill to complete. Every playthrough randomizes many locations in the game and enemy spawns, allowing the game to be very replay-able. The learning curve may be steep at first but once you have the basic mechanics down it's just a matter of playing it safe, but the game can be very deep with a great skill system opening up many different ways of surviving the post apocolyptic wasteland. Pro's : + Fantastic survival mechanics ranging from your usual hunger/thirst to illness , fatigue and comfort.+ Challenging turn based battle system based around your skills and condition. + A large variaty of items.+ Randomised loot, enemy and location spawns on every playthrough making it very fresh.+ A good story with lots of hidden treasures and ways to complete.+ Great stealth mechanics.+ A hidden reputation system.Cons :- The RNG can be absolutely infuriating sometimes, but that's the way of the roguelike.- There are very limited animations, the game is mostly text based.- At first the game is not very user friendly and the UI may be difficult to navigate. ( particularly campsites )- Extremely difficult to complete on your first few runs, requiring you to playthrough once or twice to learn which options to avoid.- Limited options for character creation.- Very limited building options for shelter / bases.All-in i would deffinitely recommend this game if you are into hardcore roguelikes, there is a lot of depth beneath the surface and the randomization and character skill system brings a variety of ways to play the game. If however, you are looking for an easy survival game to build up your own haven and sit back surviving the nights i would stay clear as NEO Scavenger can be very punishing at the worst of times.

												Despite some of the more fantastic elements of the game, such as the inclusion of monsters from urban legend, such as the Michigan dog man and the Enfield horror, this is one of the more realistic survival experiences I've seen.  most of the time, the reasons why I died had more to do with the enviroment, freezing to death especially, but also poisoning, disease, nd starvation.  aas for the combat, it also has a more realistic feel, with some fights dragging on for several minutes as you get chased through the woods, while even weaker weapons can easily cause enemies to bleed out with good strikes.  sometimes i wish certain enemy types would be more adaptive, with most raiders attacking on sight and most people running away as soon as you spot them once you get good equipment, it still a really good game.

Nevereverever take off that amulet around your neck unless you want a cool way to comit suicide. Trust me. I know things.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: May 27, 2015
												NEO Scavenger is an incredibly in-depth survival game with a real throwback feel. It *LOOKS* rough on the edges but is actually incredibly well made. * TL;DR*Well made game about making tough decisions to survive a wasteland in a rogue-like setting. Almost a Darksouls/Fallout child with survival and exploration focus. Prepare to die, pretty often, and have fun.* *The game is all about making those tough decisions. From the get go what traits you feel you'll need or use best, and what hindrances you're willing to cope with to take on all of those useful traits/skills. Fairly regular scenarios in which you make decisions based on the items you have, the skills you've acquired, and your environment, whether it be setting up camp in a crumbling building or out in the woods, to drink water of questionable origins, eating berries that may or may not be poisonous (a choice you can ignore with the botany skill), knowing eating said berries could stave your growing hunger a little longer, but also that it may end your game with you sweating and ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ your life away... unless you find the right medicines. Was that the red pill or the blue pill (should've taken the medic skill)? This game pulls no punches. It's hard, it's frustrating, and it can feel like your progressing very slowly... and you will. But you'll learn. You'll find what works for you. If that's a spear-wielding bandit, preying on others, chopping off their legs for a nice roast, go do it! If you want to hide in the forest, hunting game, living off berries and scattering sound and animal traps amidst your domain, go haunt those woods why don't you? The game's replay value is high. (Mostly) randomly generated, with no real reason to follow the story except personal interests. If you want to make a life for yourself in the wastes, there's nothing (but everything) to stop you. It cannot be recommended enough, and for the price, it's a steal!

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												This is a solid turn-based post-apocalyptic survival rogue-like (that's a lot of hyphens). I found it to be addicting and sunk a lot of hours into it when I had things that needed to get done, that's the way it goes with these types of games. Pick your starting characteristics and then wake up in a lab with something fearsome at your heals. Every action could lead to your death. It takes you a while to figure out how not to die from hunger, thirst, and exposure. Next comes figuring out whether you can handle combat and to what degree. After that you worry about what happened to you and the world, and where you need to go. All this is done while crafting or looting nearly all your equipment and dealing with the survivors of this world.You should try this game out, it's an experience you need to have.

content:
Posted: May 28, 2015
												Neo Scavenger is, in my opinion, one of the greatest survival games ever put to market.I strongly advise you to play the demo before you decide if you want to purchase this, as how you feel about the inventory system will likely make or break the game for you.It's brutal, at times tense, at times it may feel unfair, but there's genuinely no other game like it out there, especially in the survival subgenre.The combat is rough, dirty and unforgiving. Get shot? I hope to god you know how to treat that because you're not walking away until you've got that under control.  The environment is dirty, broken down and makes finding food so difficult you're likely to consider cannibalism a few times.If the price seems a bit high, play the demo a few times and see how you like it. I've already sunk 30+ hours into the game and I still haven't beaten it.

content:

Early Access Review
								I got this game AGES ago when it was MUCH less complete than it is now, and even then it was great. Since then, the game has grown by leaps and bounds, and with every new build it gets better. A post apocalyptic setting that isnt just an irradiated desert makes for an interesting environment with a lot more options. The crafting system has so much depth its rediculous. Countless items, weapons, ingredients, great resource management elements, weather systems, and a story that will slowly but surely draw you in. Permadeath is a bummer, but you can always reload a previous save. However, chosing to start again with new traits and skills is just as rewarding, with a new experience with each new game. Even the opening moments of the game will change depending on your chosen traits. I can not reccomend this game highly enough.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								To the developers I love this game I have about 15+ hours of offline play as well as my online time and it is just great I love the permadeath, random encounters and traits features. But I would like to see more traits a new start instead of just starting in the room with the dogman all the time it just gets annoying. There should also be an in game guide for beginners to get them started instead of just forcing them to learn basic features. The good thing about this game is that it makes you think ahead like should I or should I attack this enemy to get his gear Considering his weapon do I have enough medical items if I do get injured. Another one of the cool things is how suddenly a battle can change one minute you can be shooting the S**t out of the guy then the next minute he caves your head in with his crowbar.  Considering your opponent is a big thing for example I was trying to kill a melon head then he starts calling for others so I started to fight them but then my guy got tired so I had to retreat. When I got out of the combat screen I saw that all 4 hexes in front of me were filled with melon heads which would have made me pass out if I kept fighting and could have killed me.  The things that aren’t that good about this game are not very major just things like the lack of types of enemies, traits, the same starting room all the time, no beginners tutorial, some overpowered enemies, how you can only put one weapon with a strap over your shoulder, sometimes there is a lack of enemies around and there could be more items like more bags, guns, melee weapons and clothing.But overall this is one of my favorite games that I own and not just on steam out of all my games. My recommendation is to buy this game it is easily worth the $10 but I suggest that people try the demo first. Note: many features of the game are not in the demo. 10/10 for me keep up the good work developers.

												Plays like a mix of fallout, FTL type surivival games, 4x4 strategy, and an interactive novel. The guy who made it worked for Bioware, so the writing is high quality and this makes all the difference when the most dramatic scenes of the game are described entirely through text. My main complaint would be the gui, which I understand is supposed to be a throwback but ends up making very odd use of space, some buttons are just way too small or in weird places. NEO Scavenger has some rough edges but it's hard to tell what's intentionally rough and what decisions are simply quirks of the developer. Regardless, it's very hardcore and rewarding so far.

content:
Posted: January 4, 2015
												Bought this game thinking this was a simple turn based rouge like to waste time to, ended up discovering way more. Once you can get past the learning curve (even so this game will find ways to ♥♥♥♥ you, you will die A LOT), there's a lot of really interesting things that occur plot-wise. With all the traits you can choose from, there are always different ways to handle or solve things during events or otherwise. Trust me when I say that spending a lot of time with this game will be very rewarding; there are a LOT of possibilities with this game.Definitely not a game for the impatient, I wouldn't recommend this to you if you're the type of person what will give up after carefully spending many hours building up your gear and supplies, then suddenly get killed by a seemingly random or unavoidable force. To me, that only adds more to the post-apocalyptic feel. Nobody how hard you struggle, there's never a guarantee that you're actually going to survive; you're never fully in control of the situation and there's always something much bigger than you out there. Sometimes it just takes sheer luck.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2015
												Alright, so you wake up in some abandoned medical research facility, some sort of creature is pounding at the door ahead of you, using your affinity for mechanics, you lock the door and prevent it from getting in. Going outside, you notice its cold, so you scavenge a near by town for clothes, but its too late, you freeze to death.So one more try. Again, you wake up an abandoned medical facility with a monster pounding at your door. This time, you chose to excell in strength, so you decide to fight this thing head on. You take a few scratches, but otherwise you beat. Using your trapping abilities, you managed to make a cloak out of its fur, keeping you warm for the forseeable future. Right on! so you start scavenging, you come across some food, a butchers knife, so shoes. You are doing pretty good! Buuuuut remember those scratches from before? You never treated them and they got infected, so you die. Again. Third times a charm, no? So you start again. You kill the monster, you make a cloak, this time you manage to find some clean rags to cover your wounds and carry on. You scavenge, find a nice ole' shotgun to keep you safe, but you come across a stranger, you don't know much about this person so you ease your way up, you threaten them and they try to run so you blow them away. They start crawling, and you decide to finish them off and loot whats left of the innocent guys corpse. You get a little tired, so you rest in the woods when something wakes you up in the middle of the night. Its a feral dog, and oh♥♥♥♥♥♥ youre out of ammo. You decide to stick to beating the thing with the but of your gun, but its no luck. One too many bites means its game over.Incase you can't tell, you will die a lot in neoscavenger. Like...a lot a lot. The game makes no attempt to hold your hand, and that will inevitably turn some people off, while others will find this a refreshing change of pace. Neo is a tough game for sure, and the survival aspects are fantastic. Of course you have to eat, sleep, drink etc etc but you also have to make sure you don't freeze to death, make sure your wounds are tended to and don't get infected, make sure you have shoes so you don't get blisters on your feet, try and make some interesting moral choices along the way (Do you help the mother and her child escape from the cannibals? How about watching people fight to death in an arena for scraps of food?) All in all, I think Neo Scavenger is one of the gems of 2014. I didn't even know about it until searching through steams library. I think if you're a fan of the survival genre and want something that's tactical with a lot of options and a nice change of pace in terms of story other than your typical "Oh my god! Zombies!" schtick, I recommend you check it out.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is an excellent example of survival RPG, bringing to mind other isometric games like UnReal World and Haven and Hearth.  This game masters the eerie, abandoned quality present in Fallout, and is as challenging to navigate.  You will realize the painful cost of each difficult decision.That said, the game features nothing by way of world building.  You can craft your own ramshackle gear from the broken remnants of the pre-war world and the often hazardous wilderness, but you cannot cultivate, construct defenses, or harvest natural resources apart from sticks, branches, water, and a few edibles.  Everything in the game is slowly decaying, and ultimately, so are you.  If you want a sense that your character has a future other than ending up the corpse someone else scavenges, this is not the game for you.I can honestly say I feel I've had my money's worth, but I don't think I'll finish the main story line.  This game may well leave you feeling like a murderous hobo, starving, infected, insane, who would gleefully pop out of nowhere and bludgeon some random stranger to death with a tree branch for a shoddy left boot and a plastic shopping bag.  But some people who enjoy the survival genre are looking for just that.Happy hunting, you psychopath.

								Wow. Just wow. This game is hard, unforgiving, and near impossible. I love it. My last playthrough, I had taken a guides advice with slight modification of my own and I was a super power nothing could kill me, except for nature herself. I had taken down four dogman, six strangers, Ftons of melonheads, and an enfiend horror all within six hexex of each other and only minors cuts and bruises as my reward, oh and a few dozen bullets, a couple guns, water bottles, and furs out the wazzo. This was only half way through. I wasn't playing the story, I wanted to gear up, I was challenging myself out in the wilderness and it was fun! Just doing what I wanted, fighting when I had to, chatting when I didn't, and just surviving. This can be a casual game or a hardcore game it depends on how you want to play, do you want to follow the story or simply explore the whole map. But in my opinion fun is all this game is going to be. Don't mistake it though. Remeber the badass you just read up there I overestimated myself and attacked when I should have dodged with hunger and thirst nearly claiming me along the way. Thus ending my adventure but also beginning a new and, hopefully, better one.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								A surprising nuanced hex game that is heavy on survival and crafting. The game is being made primarily by one man, Dan Fedor, who is a former BioWare developer. The game is easy to learn but hard to master which gives it a certain level of replayability, especially since it is still in development. That being said, Fedor does a great job of communicating with the community, including writing out DAILY UPDATES on his website. The level of polish that the game has, even for simple things like GUI and aspect ratios is kind of amazing considering its being developed by just one guy.

content:

Early Access Review
								I cannot express my love for this game enough.I've always been a fan of minimal graphics games which can deliver such a compelling, engaging story and survival based-gameplay. Every step through the Hex world brings with it the chance to stumble on the thing you most need to survive. Or turn out to be something which leaves your bloodied, broken, bacteria-ridden body crawling back to one of the last bastions of human civilisation.When my character was dying of thirst and racing back towards the city gates, the howls of dogmen in the background, I felt every slick of the mouse which was one step closer to salvation. A rush without the need for a next-gen PC :PThe inventory management takes me back and time can be spent organising your goodies and packing the essentials close to hand.The developer is fantastic, responds to the players and is constantly evolving the game to new levels of awesomeness!Do it. Do it now. Brave the wastelands!Sidenote; multiplayer would be an awesome addition, no matter how slow it might go.

content:

Early Access Review
								NeoScavenger - 9.5/10This game is without any exaggeration, the best RPG i have ever played. The game masterfully combines survival and RPG. Harsh and Unforgiving, the game goes to great lengths to immerse the player in every aspect of surivial and exploration. Despite its vast open world game-play, the game still factors in an amazingly unique story. To those who enjoy RPGs, Survival, or Exploration games, i strongly recomend this game to you. If you are still not convinced by my ramblings, then give the free demo a try.

content:

Early Access Review
								ANOTHER terrific retro game! If you think "Under-Rail" is intriguing (another steam title) this is another gem in that vein. A perfect blend of RPG and Rogue-like, you are thrust into the post-apocalyptic world with no idea of what has happened and the whole open world to find out what the hell is going on. Brilliant turn-based fare, and really easy to get hooked on. This game reminded me of the day when games had to offer greatness in other ways, because it was before a time graphics could sell your product. Instead, it enthralls, intrigues, challenges, and keeps you drawn with it's personality. Recommended. I am so thankful games like this are still coming out!! <3

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 29, 2015
												I've played this game for fifteen hours now, not very far into it. I can make a few assertions about the game quality however. First allow me to state this fits into my desired game "style" very well. Turn-Based and Survival and two of my favorite types of games - this has both. Perma-death is also another great feature of the game. Namely, the sense if you die you have to start over is a great motivator to be extra careful while scavenging.The combat mechanics take a bit of getting used to, but once you have them down it's fairly easy to "manipulate" the encounter to be in your favor. Naturally you don't want to attack everything you see, sometimes it's wiser to stay hidden and let the group of guys with guns walk past you.The crafting system is great, it's very well thought out. I love having the ability to make a tarp shelter and after I'm done sleeping breaking it down and collecting my tarp and string to be able to move along with a smaller load.Scavenging for supplies is well done, the mechanic is both rewarding and frustrating at the same time - mainly when you're looking for something specific and keep getting trash.On my last play through I was horrifically murdered by the shop keeper. All I did was try to sell him cured human flesh, is that really so wrong?

content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Highly recomended, this game lets you do a lot that, at surface level it does not apper that it would be deep enough to allow.Example: I had just reached a little shack in the woods, I was a little low on provisions, so I desided to camp there for a little while so i could try to find water and food. While I was there two looters with guns came by and tryed to steal my stuff. I, naturaly, tryed to stop them. After all that was all my stuff. They shot me a couple of times, and while a was sitting on the floor looseing blood they made off with my backpack full of stuff and most of my medical equipment. I dressed my wounds as best I could, and went to get some water and something to eat. I was banged up, but I would live. Then as i was headed back to my shack, I eat some poisonous berries and died.If you think that sounds frustrating, it was, but that is not the games fault, it was mine. You learn from your mistakes and you get better, could not recomend this game any more than I am right now, buy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 2, 2015
												NEO SCAVENGER is a game driven by the stories you write. In one run you could be a survivor who runs around collecting berries and putting them into a bag of chips and in the other run you could be a medic who finds a sniping rifle which he uses to kill other survivors to claim their stuff. There are endless possibilities. Another great aspect is that everything is textbased and menu based, You are telling your own individual all in your head. If NEO SCAVENGER would've been a more visual dependent game then it wouldn't have been that great! It's just you and nature fighting against each other and it's beautiful. NEO SCAVENGER is the best and most realistic survival  game out there. Definitely give this one a try!

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 20, 2015
												>Run into guy with Yukon backpack and bow>Decide to rob him>Guy has no arrows for his bow, I'm armed with a spear. Fight takes two seconds and he's knocked out>Take his bow and backpack, but decide to show mercy and leave my spear with him (wont be needing it now, planning to maker arrows at next campsite) to give this poor NPC ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ a shot>Get a few hexes away from my unconcious victim and set up camp, make arrows, prepare for next day.>Get woken up in the middle of the night by sounds around my campsite, cant see♥♥♥♥♥♥>Keep looking around to see anything>Suddenly I see the spear I left behind, it's in my chest.>♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ hit me straight in the heart.>I die instantly.10/10 would die by karma again.A really fun survival game set in a post apocalyptic world that's got a pretty unique form of apocalypse (or at least I don't think I've seen many other games with this sort of apocalypse) surviving in this world is challenging, food and water are hard to come by, and eating anything that wasn't cleaned properly could screw you over in the long run. The combat system is pretty interesting (altough I wish they'd impliment a different stamina system, so you wouldn't feel like taking a nap right after caving a mutants skull in). The story I described earlier is completley unscripted and just happened all on its own, as are pretty much all of the stories in the review, they might not happen to you personally but you'll probably have your own unique story of that one awesome/hilarious death. I definitley recommend the game to anyone who wants a challenging survival experience.

												I was honestly extremely skeptical about this game for its appearance and price tag. However, that skepticism turned out to be about as valid as trying to say that FTL isn't a good game because its graphics are primitive—the actual gameplay is masterful. I have been at this non-stop for maybe ten hours, and there's still obvious signs of endless story left. If you are the kind of person who plays Fallout New Vegas on Hardcore, has ever played a game of Rifts in your life, ever went on an Outward Bound and found it a little too tame, or just appreciates an all-consuming survival horror game; then this is for you. If it's on sale, it's definitely for you; but I've paid more for games I've liked a lot less!

												All-righty, nothing like waking up from a nice long cryo slumber with nothing but a hospital gown, a wrist-Band, and a 1970's medallion to your name. Then immediately being assailed by a cross between Cujo and Hulk Hogan, which causes you to flee for your life into the wastelands  of Detroit...(Which oddly enough is a lot like present day Detroit). It is all good for a while drink a little scavenged H2O and some berries ( I suggest the Botany Skill ). Ahh yes you can feel the rumble in your tunny as the unfiltered and tainted water begins to take it's toll. Soon you are crapping blood and running for your life to find the nearest tree so you can prolapse your♥♥♥♥♥♥, congratulations in the not so distant future amoebic dysentery is alive and well . After crapping yourself into the who's who book of The Screaming Squats, you realize you are now suffering from hypothermia...but it is ok you can pretty much scavenge , salvage, and construct most anything. That is of course if the Melon-Heads, and Bad Mutha do not find you and make you "Squeell Like a Big Boy! CAUSE YOU SURE DO GOTS A PERTTY MOUTH!". MAYBE YOU LOOSE IT AND AXE MURDER THE WHOLE LOT OF THEM WHILE THEY SLEEP...!Just do not eat them, eating human meat is for Punks...dont be a Punk, harvest a berry or eat a shroom....then start beating feat again...Just understand you are gona die...maybe you'll freeze or starve, or crap yourself to death, get eaten, electrocuted....who knows,but it will happen....But it is OK, because this is one fun as hell game...It will not try to dazzle you with BS, no super flashy graphics to hide the fact that it sux more than a ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ named Eureka..No, see because if you took this game from Samuel L Jackson and dropped it in a bag of other games, and then same told you to give him his Sh*% back and you asked which one was his...Sam would tell you...It is the game that has Bad Mutha f%$#$% written on it. Listen if you have 15 or so bucks do yourself a favor and buy this game, buy it play it and then watch your character die horribly and love enjoy it.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
												So I've played this a bit before release so you know... Playtime not entirely accurate.I don't really have much to say or add but here goes:It's a minimalist, roguelike, RPG that manages to be intruiging without any visual elements. Obviously there are visuals and not just text, but they serve more to simplify the UI. The UI is pretty great honestly and it's something a lot of these hardcore roguelikes just don't give a crap about, so it's a breath of fresh air to say the least.I love the addition of the ambient soundeffects and the music. It livens up the experience quite a bit and makes it easier to immerse yourself.To sum things up: it's immersive like a great text adventure. Lots of descriptive text and important decisions with the addition of much needed visuals and soundeffects.It's just really solid and I recommend it if you like great text adventures and hardcore roguelikes. Just don't expect a flashy presentation.

												Good lord is this game hard.Trust me when I say this, this game holds no punches. Think pixelated turn-based STALKER. It's one of the best games I've played in a while. Turn-based combat is normally a huge hurdle for me, but this game does it really well. You WILL end up being so hungry you will resort to cannibalism (No, really, this game has cannibalism). All the combat is text based, but instead of leaving a lot to be desired, it lets you imagine how the event played out. Were you tripped and are desperatly trying to grab at your attacker or are you secretly planning to show weakness right before you lash out with a concealed knife? It's one of the more original titles out there and it's not in early access anymore. But don't take my word for it, try the demo! (Word of warning though, the demo is a lot worse than the full game)ADHD Version: Bash people's face in with a rock so you can steal their pants.

content:

Early Access Review
								Let's get this out of the way first - This is my first review.NEO Scavenger has a lot of potential. The gameplay so far is amazing, and the combat and scavenging system works really well, making it all the more impressive. I really can't wait to see the finished product, although there are a few things I want to point out.The scavenging system is great and all, but it is REALLY brutal unless you get lucky. Probably 8/10 times I played through the game and I died before I survived 1 day. It is really hard to find any kind of clothing even when there is a high loot chance in the scavenging screen.And when I get to the DMC Gates, as soon as I complete Hatter's request for the Urn, he gives me the pass for the DMC gates, but when I get scanned, it still won't let me in, and as well as that, it breaks after I finished a few turns, even when it's durability is at 100% (even after a few playthroughs this still happened) and I'm not sure if this is a game breaking bug or something is wrong with my NEO Scavenger.Still, even in Beta and it's well worth the £7 I paid for it. I recommend this HEAVILY to any RPG/Post Apocalyptic players who like any of the original Fallout series - 9/10.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								I would have enjoyed NEO Scavenger if it didn't "end" so abruptly. There is so much more to want. Otherwise, the game is addictive, difficult, and has an dark desolate atmosphere. The first two games of the Fallout series has brought about a morbid curiosity about the surviving in a wasteland for many years. NEO Scanvenger does really well giving a complex some-what realistic survival system. The main things to be concerned about is food, water, shelter, warmth, and health while giving curveballs with dealing with other humans. This game really tests your morality with your drive to survive while requiring you to come up with clever solutions to problems to continue to live. I would recomend this game to anyone with interests in survival and adventure.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 30, 2014
Early Access Review
								One Part Fallout/Wasteland, One Part Text Adventure, One Part Roguelike (or Dark Souls if you're trendy), and One Part Survival/Horror make up this indie game. You wake up in a cryogenic sleep chamber with no clues as to who you are, where you are, or what the hell is going down. All you wake up with is a hospital gown on your back, and a dogmanbeast right down the hall way that looks hungry. The game at first is hard as balls as you learn to survive out in the wilderness. Combat is brutal, with the persistent wounds (bleeding, head trauma, cuts/scrapes/scars) that affect your performance. Survival is even worse as you need to juggle hunger, hydration, and health all at once as you travel the wasteland. But after your few first brutal deaths you will eventually start to catch on and make your way further into the harsh post-apocalytpic scenery. Eventually you'll make your way into an actually populated city where the story begins to develop and the game begins to flex its Text Adventure muscles.NEO Scavenger is EARLY ACCESS as ♥♥♥♥ but shows plenty of potential due to a fairly ugly and not-so-user friendly UI, lack of toturial, and just general lack of polish or explanation for its myriad of features. For hardxcore gamers who aren't afraid of getting their♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s handed to them on a bloody platter a few times, or those who are roguelike veterans, pick this up.
