number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 30, 2015
												Despite its aged graphics and less than perfect UI this is a real gem of a post apocalyptic survival game. It can be truly unforgiving, but that to me was one of the things that drew me into the world of NEO Scavenger. The survival aspect is a lot more engaging to me than most other survival type games I've played, and you quickly learn to pick your battles very carefully. Just like in reality, a single wound can end up killing you if you're careless and don't have access to modern medicine, and nature itself can be equally lethal. This is something I've found to be missing from most other survival games. The story is fairly interesting as well, but some of the choice based encounters are a bit harsh. And losing a character that survived for a long time in one of those is rarely fun. Still, the game kept drawing me back in until I had beaten it, and I'm looking forward to what the developer has in store for us next.If you want a challenge, love the roguelike aspect of dead is dead in a post apocalyptic setting and can look past the graphics then you can't really go wrong with this game.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 18, 2015
												Despite it's low-fi visuals and text-based combat/feedback (leaving much of the action unfortunately to your imagination), NEO Scavenger still gave me plenty of chills with its eerie atmosphere, attention to detail, music, and RNG events. The game forces you to weigh the consequences of any action you do, and be timely about it. There's a lot of replayability since you can choose from a wide arrange of skills and strengths/weaknesses at the start, which will alter your decision-making and options.I have a short play-time since I mostly played the demo, but it's a surprisingly complex game that more survival games should take notes from. The vibe is spot-on; creepy, harsh, and very mysterious.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: August 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really like Neo Scavenger. That's why there will be a long, LONG review on it. To Start, in even a short time of five hours, this game has left a great impression on me, from death to art style to dialogues... It's brilliant to begin with.Gameplay: You wake up in the middle of Michigan in some sort of year, in which humanity is back to the dark ages. Heal yourself, fight, scavenge, explore, talk, DAMN. And more. Every choice is better then Mass Effect's Endings and choices. DAAAAMN. 10/10Story/Quests: Survive in the apocalypse, find out who you are, DUN DUN DUN! Kinda cliche, but I will give the quests and random encounters credit. 7/10Dialogues: Pretty long, and most of the lore is delivered through it, which was somewhat of a let-down. However, the dialogue was good. I'll shame it for it's lack of a Dialogue Tree thus far. 7/10AI: The AI was great. Enemies were either cowards or knew how to fight, and their AI reflected that. With the combat system, it sets up a difficulty of COMPLEXITY, and that's either really good or bad game design. Here, it's done great. 8/10World Design: Semi-Dynamic, beautifully designed, randomly generated. It's luck, but damn good luck. 9/10Graphics: The game is set up in a 32-bit art style (I believe?), and the graphics look promising. Some shots of the world are detailed, even with 32 pixels. This game would have great graphics back in the 32-bit era, and good indie graphics. 8/10Sound: Haha. None. 0/10Music: There is a death track, thus far. Nothing special. 4/10The verdict for NEO Scavenger is an 8.75/10. It delivers well, and it's promising, even for late Early Access. Some small tweaks, and this could easily go over a 9.DayZ Review Gimmick: "Slept in an office, robbed and left with my plastic bag. 8.75/10, would sleep again."

								I'm really enjoying this game, except for a couple of details.- Picking [Strong] [Melee] [Tough] is overpowered. If anything. ANYTHING comes within melee range and you're carrying a branch, they can kill their♥♥♥♥♥goodbye.Got a rifle? Nevermind the bullets, just use the gun's butt and turn them into a greasy paste.- If you get a disease, that's pretty much the end of the game. I was in an extremely profitable run, but caught dysenteria, then bloated, then the symptoms subsided. It came back not long after, then I reached "the lights" and I traded almost everything for a medikit, which couldn't do anything to save my life.- There's an enemy that will call for reinforcements in the middle of a fight. While this is an interesting and welcome mechanic, IT DOESN'T MEAN THEY ARE CALLING MONSTERS FROM NEARBY HEXES. THEY ARE GENERATING MORE OF THEM. I got into a fight with one of them, I was hiding and using a slingshot and by the time I managed to kill the first, 4 more had shown up. By the time I killed the next, 3 more had appeared. I kept picking them off, but more kept being summoned.Had it not been for the lack of ammo, I wonder if they would've kept spawning infinitely?- It's turn based, but sometimes my actions are limited. Sometimes I get 5 actions per turn, sometimes, I just get 1, and I get no explanation as to why.Like any good roguelike, it relies in random chance.It has a very interesting crafting system that uses the skills you picked and an array of "substitute materials" in which it specifies what *kind* of item you need to craft."Waterproof, fireproof container" may refer to a pan or a glass bottle, "sharp edge" may be a piece of glass, a shiv, or a knife...It's a very interesting game, which is a bit frustrating at times. If you get out of a bad fight alive, you're likely to die anyway.Combat is turn-based with options for actions, which will vary depending on what you picked for skills. For example, picking [Tough] will allow you to headbutt an oponent sometimes, and the [Trapping] skill will let you lure an enemy into a makeshift trap.Crafting is relatively easy. Drop the right items and skills into a grid, click the "craft" button, presto. You got yourself a new bow.In the end, yes, it's still early access, but it's still fun, complex and interesting. I had a smile on my face when I fought a big, furry monster barehanded, took no damage, and got a "video recording of you beating the crap out of a wolf-man barehanded".I like a game with a sense of humor.

content:
Posted: June 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I just wanted to do what I can to try and promote this amazing game. I am absolutely loving it and I think it deserves a little more praise and hype. It's a single player, post-apocalyptic, turn based, permadeath, hex-mapped, rogue-like, rpg. I love these flavour of games and now that I have a tiny baby to look after these days, I thought I might try something more 'pausable' because I may have to suddenly be elbow deep in doodie duty at a moment's notice. Which is something that you just can't reconcile with games of unforgiving immediacy like DayZ.There are some great intro tutorial videos on Youtube that explain the slightly foreign quirks of what is basically a gui format you should be comfortable with.There is a free demo version available on the Steam Store, so you can check it out fearlessly before making up your mind.Should be a big hit with my Tabletop folks.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 2, 2016
												A challenging, clunky, and surprisingly deep survival sim.Best: Atmospheric, procedural game world interspersed with story events and areasBrutal but fair survival sim keeps you coming back, learning new tricks each timePerks grant new info about the sim mechanics (eg playing Medical allows you to see your health bars)Modding to allow saves or grant more perks adds greatly to already high replayabilityWorst: Not a lot of explaining done, only partial visibility of what's happening under the hood, mechanically. If you're the kind of optimizing player who needs to know how many units of hunger a gummibear diminishes, you'll be stuck spending some time on a poorly-maintained wiki looking for clues.Awkward UI for a modern gameUnpredictable responses from game engine (ie autosort ground inventory when away from camp) discourages late-game experimentationInefficiency makes for a time-suckMy strong recommendation for NEO hinges on the opinion that the simple mechanics support a compelling emergent narrative. Repeatedly clicking the "kick when down" option in combat, each time seeing your fallen opponent gain increasingly grisly status conditions, packed a surprising emotional punch. And that's what this game is going for: drawing engaging story moments of wilderness and post-apocalyptic survival from austere gameplay elements. Never in a game have you been so happy to find a plastic bag, so afraid of a lone dog, so desperate for a drink of clean water. The very central crafting system, while inefficient, is fairly intuitive and visually interesting. After I'd played for a while, a central occupation became setting up camps decorated with the bones of my enemies. The story was interesting, though you'll have to play hard or get lucky to see all of it. Modding to allow saves broke the game in that it destroyed the haggard, roguelike grind for survival. How quickly, failing to plan ahead, you'll find yourself surrounded by a pack of dogs or caught out in the open at night makes every decision important, and the longer you survive the more is at stake. Without saves, however, I wasn't able to gather the resources necessary to explore the hacking and electronics mechanics, or to wholeheartedly play the story encounters, which are often deadly, without being afraid of losing my entire enterprise to a single bad decision. Then again, that's exactly what NEO is all about.

I'm still raging about it and I'm still playing this game, because I can't ♥♥♥♥ing beat it, yet it's really a blast. Seriously one of my favorite games.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								NEO Scavenger is an excellent example of survival RPG, bringing to mind other isometric games like UnReal World and Haven and Hearth.  This game masters the eerie, abandoned quality present in Fallout, and is as challenging to navigate.  You will realize the painful cost of each difficult decision.That said, the game features nothing by way of world building.  You can craft your own ramshackle gear from the broken remnants of the pre-war world and the often hazardous wilderness, but you cannot cultivate, construct defenses, or harvest natural resources apart from sticks, branches, water, and a few edibles.  Everything in the game is slowly decaying, and ultimately, so are you.  If you want a sense that your character has a future other than ending up the corpse someone else scavenges, this is not the game for you.I can honestly say I feel I've had my money's worth, but I don't think I'll finish the main story line.  This game may well leave you feeling like a murderous hobo, starving, infected, insane, who would gleefully pop out of nowhere and bludgeon some random stranger to death with a tree branch for a shoddy left boot and a plastic shopping bag.  But some people who enjoy the survival genre are looking for just that.Happy hunting, you psychopath.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I want to love this game, I really really do. I still would suggest it to people who like rogue-like(lite) games, and enjoy the survival because the survival is incredibly well done. I’m akso sure I will play more hours of this as time goes. With that said, my main issue is, unlike a lot of other permadeath games, this one has a story to tell, which might take you a long time to figure out when first playing, and it seems really interesting. The problem is, very few will ever get to experience that story as no matter how you gear up or character build, your character has the staying power of a lit candle in a hurricane. Little to nothing can stop a low or average enemy from getting in a lucky shot that will knock you out or kill you in one blow, costing you hours of game time. You will lose anything and everything you were working on. Having to re-create a character and starting again with the repetitive cryo facility wake-up scene. I understand this is the concept of this genre, but to have nothing left after working so hard to build up a character and losing 3-5 hours, for me, is frustrating. There are some who may love that, though. Once again, it’s not the permadeath for me, as much as it is the lucky cheap-shot.There are several mods for it already, though most just give more items and such. There are no saving mods as of yet, and the only way that truly seems to provide a means to see the story is some kind of invulnerability mod. Though removing the challenge entirely isn’t any fun at all. There is also a great mod out there that gives limited repair features that help shift the gameplay.With that said, the scavenging and survival system is absolutely incredible. Sometimes it can be a little over-complicated when you first play, but as a general rule most recipes make logical sense. Found a shard of glass? Use it as a cutting tool, wrap it with a piece of paper for a makeshift shiv, or use it as a weapon in dire need at the risk of cutting yourself. Found a glass bottle? Smash it and use it to threaten off an enemy. Use clean water or whiskey to sterilize your wounds before using those rags you sterilized in boiled water to stem the bleeding.The survival is the strongest aspect of this game and it shines over everything. From having to keep warm, to managing your health. Accidentally drank some bad water? Got sepsis from that wound you forgot to clean? You better find a place to hunker down and heal up with that bottle of anti-biotics you found in the locked shed with your makeshift lockpicks. Forage some wood and keep that fire going to stay warm and keep your immune system up, but make sure you set up some noise traps because people and…things can see it burning.The in-depth survival system makes this an amazing game to enjoy overcoming what I have said above, which is why I still suggest it. To see an indie dev put together a system that a AAA company could never have the creativity to pull off is a breath of fresh air. A game that will make you♥♥♥♥♥♥your pants in excitement just for finding a shopping cart.

content:
Posted: November 20, 2015
												Have you ever watched shows like Man vs Wild, Survivorman, Naked and Afriad (title is very similar to the early game, lol), and a host of other survival-based shows and thought, "I would like to know what that is like, but I don't want to die."This is the answer.There are many horrifing, diabolical, grusome ways you can expire which include, but not limited to:-Starvation-Hypothermia-Sniped from 60 yards away by a UAV-Sniped from 60 yards away by an angry canibal with a hunting rifle and a scope-Blue Rot (like smallpox, but not)-Cholera (*Painful flashbacks to Oregon Trail*)-Gettind fried alive by an ADS (Area Denial System)-Getting your intrails forceably removed by a Dogman-Eating the wrong mushrooms-Eating the right mushrooms, and drinking infected water-Going to the house by the lake-Taking off your Copper Talisman-AND MANY MORE!!!!In all seriousness, it may be a flash game, but it's better than the majority of Triple-A Games released in the past 2 years.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
												A friend of mine designs games and I wanted him to make a game where you were dropped into the desert and had to use what was around you to survive. He said he was too busy making aa tank game called shellshock skirmish, so im glad to have gotten round to finally purchasing neo scavenger. After being on my wishlist for a long time I picked it up on sale and its worth it and worth spending the time on. Using your brain to figure things out rather than being on a guided tour is a refreshing aspect not allowed in many games and theres plenty of small details and replayability to be had. Not a game for those who enjoy giving up as you will die many times, each time figuring things out more and more. On one of my plays through I had a good haul of equipment 7 days in and was progressing with the story (there is a story, you have to find it!) when I stupidly setup camp in a bad place and was murdered in my sleep, in another playthrough after just making it to the east coast i died from an infection from having drunk infected water on the trip!All together this is worth your time and the turn based nature allowd you to relax and play alongside doing something else like checking your emails or cooking :)

content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												In my last run, I found myself holed up in the cryo facility, which I'd made into quite the comfortable little strong-hold, with electric light, a comfortable bed, the works.  I'd only leave to collect water, firewood, or go hunting.  I could use the firewood to boil the water, and cook the food.  I scavanged what I could nearby, but that part of the map is pretty well picked-over.  I could get back to the barter-town and plot line, probably, but it'd be a lot easier if I could repair my push-cart.  I guess I'll chill at my chateau till the right parts show up on one of my few scavenging trips (I still need lighters from time to time, after all).  I'm armed enough that most critters and people in that part of the world aren't really a threat.  Yep, life is actually pretty good.  I'm thinking about taking up some farming, maybe learn to play an instrument, or ferment my own wine from the less poisonous berries around here.  I think I win the game, at this point, don't I?

												Frighteningly realistic. Can be difficult to get into but very hard to put down. Story is vague, and you have to pick it up in pieces. Character creation needs some work still, but it's fine. Some of the permadeath aspects can really suck, like how in certain encounters 2 out of the 4 choices will kill you. However this is compensated for with beautiful writing and detail. Combat is one of the best aspects of the game, it feels fresh, rewarding, and pretty realistic. Your first playthrough and your later playthroughs will have such a big difference, it's crazy. If you can't afford the kind of big price tag, I recommend the demo at the least. That has the combat.

Let me describe this game's pros and cons       Pros -              Great survival mechanisms ( Eg . Crafting, tiredness? )             Good story ( not great )             MODDING ( YAY! )             Great Community             Big open world ( including little bit of wildlife and enemies )             Personal favourite - It has real life mythical creatures ( One can pluck your eyes out )             If you liked Dayz you'll probably like this game             Can run on almost every PC. content:
Posted: February 14, 2016
												In my last run, I found myself holed up in the cryo facility, which I'd made into quite the comfortable little strong-hold, with electric light, a comfortable bed, the works.  I'd only leave to collect water, firewood, or go hunting.  I could use the firewood to boil the water, and cook the food.  I scavanged what I could nearby, but that part of the map is pretty well picked-over.  I could get back to the barter-town and plot line, probably, but it'd be a lot easier if I could repair my push-cart.  I guess I'll chill at my chateau till the right parts show up on one of my few scavenging trips (I still need lighters from time to time, after all).  I'm armed enough that most critters and people in that part of the world aren't really a threat.  Yep, life is actually pretty good.  I'm thinking about taking up some farming, maybe learn to play an instrument, or ferment my own wine from the less poisonous berries around here.  I think I win the game, at this point, don't I?

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												The best word for this game is 'harsh', I reckon. It just doesn't care about you if you screw up. This makes it incredibly satisfying to succeed in. Gameplay wise scavenging is gritty and engaging, combat is incredibly serious, and crafting is pretty satisfying. The UI is pretty weak, especially in crafting and managment, but it all works fine once you suss it out. The story has been pretty compelling so far. I was blown away by how they executed Detroit, I haven't seen anything quite like it before. That said I have only managed to get to it once, and it seems a sort of first stop for the plot to really start rolling. If you like survival games give it a crack!

												a truly brutal survival sim, if you dont go in with a plan you will die. bravado is not a thing that is rewarded, it is to be punished with bone shattering realism. if you dont respect the game, the game will chew you up and spit you back out. this game is not something a more casual gamer should buy, only people who have played other unforgiving survival sims (such as Sunless Sea) will be able to grasp the difficulty of this game. despite its unforgiving style, it is enjoyable. if you liked the sheer scale of map size and exploration in games like Fallout or Oblivion you will like exploring NEO Scavenger, and crafting makes sense. There is a lot of text story, and the game lets you imagine much of how you interact with its world.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 22, 2016
												I have discovered my true calling as a hobo, fighting off feral dogs to scavenge post-apocalyptic ruins for anything remotely valuable.This game is quite good. It's actually very short, which is probably a good thing because it's so difficult. However, despite the amount of random ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t that seems to kill you in this game, I never had a death where that I couldn't see why it was my fault. The world is extremely harsh, but you'll mostly find out about the stuff that kills you early in the game, or it's common sense, so you won't get to the endgame only to be insta-killed unless YOU do something stupid. Just be aware that the minute you DO do anything stupid, you will probably die. This, together with the core gameplay around surviving, is what kept me coming back to the game, even after ragequitting in frustration and deciding to never play it again. The different systems around survival -health, scavenging, combat, crafting, character creation, bartering, and inventory - work together extremely well. I have a weakness for survival and sandbox games, especially rogue-like survival games, but I'm also very harsh on them. I have a lot of problems with games like Minecraft, Rust, Ark, Terraria, DayZ and more. NEO Scavenger has been the perfect survival experience for me though. It's not something to spend hundreds of hours on, no. Based on my playtime so far and the playtime of other reviewers, 70ish hours seems to be the cap before interest dives. That's when I felt like I had thoroughly learned how the game worked. What makes this an engaging experience is going from knowing nothing about the game to being able to take on any challenge it thows at you. Amazingly, it succeeds in being an experience both fantastic and realistic.It's not perfect, of course. The story events and random events have some problems, but even though these choose-your-own-adventure style events can kill you, they're actually surprisingly lenient compared to the core mechanics of the game. You usually have to screw up pretty bad to get killed, and most frequently you just get a slap on the hand if you didn't choose exactly the right path through event. Since I died so much outside of the events, it was pretty fun to see how different paths and different character builds affected the outcome. Other than that, I personally couldn't care about the story and events very much. It's interesting, moderately good quality, and original. I normally love narrative and world-building in games, but in NEO Scavenger it took the backseat to the core gameplay. The only negative thing I can say about that is it could just use MORE. The art style, while flat, is exactly what it needs to be for the game, but everything definitely looks the same after only an hour or two. If there were a few more hex-types and some variation in textures, and especially if there was some physical depth, as in changes in elevation, to the terrain, it would be much more visually interesting. The item count is decent, but if there was just a bit more customization possible it would be awesome, and then every single npc wouldn't look identical. The map is actually quite large, and it can take a long time to get across it when you're looting everything that's even slightly lootable and fending off all manner of dangers along the way, but it could really use a few more unique locations with events tied to them, even though I said that's not what I'm here for. The character building is great: it really does feel like original Fallout and it totally determines what you can do and how you play, but for a system so deep it just feels so small. The world NEO Scavenger takes place in is very interesting, but outside of vague newspaper articles there's not actually all that much to explain it all. With a more cohesive and expansive lore, I could really get into this world. The story, like I said, is very short, and I frankly don't care that much about it; it's good enough for me. But it does have this interesting problem that unless you explore everything you can easily "complete" the story in just two "quests". It's pretty hard to tell what kind of story NEO Scavenger wants to tell, and how. I don't think it needs to be longer. With multiple paths and endings and the difficulty of the game it benefits from being short. But it does need a few more storytelling mechanics, and probably a better, more dense distribution of the story throughout the gameplay. As is, you play the core game and progress for a long while, and then you get a big chunk of wall-of-text story.All in all, if you want a solid survival role-playing game, this is what you want. I think that for the type of people who enjoy this game you can expect as much as 70 hours of extremely engaging time with this game, which is definitely worth $15. Enjoy!

												Really great game! Extensive crafting, skill trees and story telling. Who really needs graphics to enjoy a game, this game does great with its unique graphics style and turn based actions. No matter how many times you die, you keep reaching for the NEW GAME button and end up trying all sorts of different skill sets which will completely change the style of play, from sneaking around in forest harvesting for recources or killing everything you see then eating their corpse in a worse case scenario. content:
Posted: February 13, 2016
												Frighteningly realistic. Can be difficult to get into but very hard to put down. Story is vague, and you have to pick it up in pieces. Character creation needs some work still, but it's fine. Some of the permadeath aspects can really suck, like how in certain encounters 2 out of the 4 choices will kill you. However this is compensated for with beautiful writing and detail. Combat is one of the best aspects of the game, it feels fresh, rewarding, and pretty realistic. Your first playthrough and your later playthroughs will have such a big difference, it's crazy. If you can't afford the kind of big price tag, I recommend the demo at the least. That has the combat.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2015
												Get this game only if you like hardcore roguelike games that doesn't give you any slake. While I enjoyed the fact that this game seemed to be a love letter to Fallout 1/2 with it's turnstyle controls and combat, the luck factor in this game will often be against you if you are starting out. You will die a LOT in the first playthroughs, but if you retain your experiences from those playthroughs you'll be able to survive long enough to progress on the storyline.It is a good survival game that is worth the price but my only complaints are that it feels a bit empty what with only a handful of locations to visit on a giant map. There are random encounters, but most of the time, they tend to be to your disadvantage unless you save beforehand. The major thing is that this game has permadeath ie. you lose EVERYTHING when you die...including your savefile. Unless you manage to make a backup of your savefile, you will have to start at the beginning everytime you die and that will be the breaking point for gamers interested in getting this.Finally, my last grip is that there will be no new content added to the game by the creator. However, there is a growing Mod community for the game an the creator made the game itself to be moddable. Hell you can even play around with the xml file of the game itself to adjust the game to your liking, though you'll have to go to the game's forums to learn more on that.All in all, if you enjoy survival turnbased games dealing with post-apocalypse and supernatural themes with good story, crafting and (more importanly) mods to extend the game , then buy this. If not, then Project Zomboid might be more your thing.

Posted: January 7, 2015
												This was one of my first buys on steam and my introduction into rogue-like games. I started palying this game in early access and learned to love this game. Despite the simple graphics and mesic do not be fooled this game is deep and difficult. I've lsot count of the number of times I've died. Sometimes it's heat stroke, or dysentery, other times it was a Bad Mutha smahing my head in like a pumkin in the middle of the night, I've been suffocated under a pack of Melon Heads and knocked out by scavengers. I've spent days having diarrhea after eating the wrong berries. Spent many sleepless nights waiting in dark abandoned apartment complexs for a pack of Dogmen to come and rip me to shreds. And despite all the deaths, all the battles,  and sleepless nights I keep on playing because the map is vast and there are so many places to go and people to talk to. Because the lore of the game is hidden in a multitude of places and despite the number of times I've lived and died at Zom Zom's I still come back for the BBQ

												This is a great game, atleast if you like a game to punish every single mistake you make. becuse this game is unforgiving, which I personally love about it. It features a advanced crafting and talent system that lets you survive the harsh landscape in many different ways. Some skills are more usefull than others but non the whole you can play it in differently each time. The one thing that I miss is a save system. Sure its nice that the game is grueling hard, but more times then not, combat comes down to pure chance. A guy with a rock can get a lycky hit which makes you blead internally and kill you in two rounds, when you are far into the game that really blows. A savesystem that only works at a few key-locations would be nice.On the whole this game is a great experience!

												This game is pretty amazing. The first time you play, maybe you don't die in the first minute. The second time you play, maybe you actually make it out of the first room. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												First of all, go ahead and play the demo, it is very representative of the game and if you like it, you are going to like the game.The tension this game puts you through is remarkable, you will find yourself analyzing the tiniest details, making sure you won't wake up in the night being slaughtered by a wolfman.There are, however, a couple of things I personally would've liked to know before I played the game. I'll put these in spoilers in case you want to find everything out by yourself: If a weapon has a strap, you can carry it by pointing at the shoulder of the character in the menu. Also, some bags can be carried over the left shoulder. The biggest problem this game has is bugs. Unfortunately, they can be truly devastating. Once, I loaded my game and the progress on the map was completely gone, so I could not see what I have seen in the past. If you take anything away from this review, let it be this:The game, despite my hours played, is actually really short. Once you have managed to master the mechanics (which will take at least 30 hours I would say), you can finish the game in a couple of hours.I was very disappointed when the ending screen appeared, because I thought now that I mastered the game I could use all my skills to explore the world and getting stronger.Anyway, the game was worth playing and I hold it in high regard.

												An amazing turn based survival game. The combat is very realistic and brutal and the survival aspects are awesome. Despite the graphical style it feels more vivid to me than games like Fallout. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 26, 2015
												This is a wonderful game.  It is unforgivingly difficult, but very satisfying when you weather the storm and stabilize.It allows many viable builds which will vary your play style significantly, although you will always play as a desperate scavenger.  Learning the survival systems and how to manage each is fun and engaging.  And it always feels wonderful when you discover the tools you need to make it another few days be it the means to make fire, clothes to stay warm, something to boil water in, or a large bag/sled to haul your stuff.Although it seems unfair at times (such as when you are killed in your sleep without a chance to act) the real choice you made came earlier when you did (or were not able to) make a safe camp with noise traps.I have one major gripe with the game is that the story elements, while immersive, tend to be too deadly, either ending your run prematurely, forcing you into a trial and error state to learn the proper choices, or spoiling the story by looking up the solution on the wiki.  While the rest of the game is fair but difficult, and revolves around the choices/play style of that run, these only involve foreknowledge of what is coming up and the time it took to prepare for it.Even so, it remains one of the best indie games I've ever played.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 24, 2015
												One of my favorite rougelike games in recent memory. I actually really enjoyed learning all the mechanics of survival, and going from only being able to survive for less than a day reliabily to learning how to survive for days and weeks on end was really rewarding.I must have spent 30 hours learning the systems, and around 2-3 hours for a winning run. I only wish that there was more content: it felt like the game was only just getting started by the time I had won. Then again, I guess it does make sense to end the game when you're getting a run to the point where you're pretty self sufficiant. It could get a bit boring otherwise.

content:
Posted: November 1, 2016
												Plays like a mix of fallout, FTL type surivival games, 4x4 strategy, and an interactive novel. The guy who made it worked for Bioware, so the writing is high quality and this makes all the difference when the most dramatic scenes of the game are described entirely through text. My main complaint would be the gui, which I understand is supposed to be a throwback but ends up making very odd use of space, some buttons are just way too small or in weird places. NEO Scavenger has some rough edges but it's hard to tell what's intentionally rough and what decisions are simply quirks of the developer. Regardless, it's very hardcore and rewarding so far.
